editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A Modern Eay On the Tenth SATYR OF JUVENAL.
By HENRY HIGDEN, Equire.
Licened June 2d. 1686. Ro. L'Etrange.
Ridendo Monet.
LONDON: Printed by T. M. and are to be Sold by Randal Taylor near Stationers-Hall, 1687.

div.head: To the Right Honourable RICHARD, LORD LUMLEY, Baron of LMLEY, AND Vicount LMLET in Ireland, &c.
div.p:
THE Knowledge I have of Your Lordhips Great Worth and Honour, is the Motive that puhes me to Publih this Piece under Your Lordhips Patronage, whoe Name and Character is o Illutrious, that it was impoible for me to Reit uch a Powerful Attraction: But when I reflect on the Poornes of the Preent and Preenter, and from thence advance my Thoughts, to conider the Grandeur of my Patron, I dicover my Want of Ability to render You the Jut Attributes of your Merit: Who beides Your Lordhips Hereditary Vertues, poes o many Excellent acquired Ones, the Contemplation whereof
fills me with Raptures and Tranports too Exquiite for a Decription. With this Impotence I wholly deit from a Panegyrick in this Epitle, the general Topick of Dedications, having o Jut an Excue for the Want of Mine, which would be wholly unneceary, ince Your Lordhips Vertues are o Eminent and Conpicuous, they want neither a Herauld nor an Hitorian.

I was concious to my Self (My Lord) of an unpardonable piece of Confidence in this Addres, in laying o Poor a Trifle at Your Lordhips Feet. But, alas! What boots the Sene of a Fault, without being able to Reit the Temptation of Committing it? Beides, the Conideration that I was already Lited in the Gang of Scriblers, and commenced a Brother of the Quill, who of all Mankind are the leat apt to have their Modety or Concience fly into their Faces: The Mues themelves (under favour) being thought but a ort of light Rambling Gypies; and of o deep an Affrican Complexion, that they were never oberved to Redden, for all their daily Preumptions and Extravagancies; and Whipping (as Experience has Taught us) does but raie and provoke their Mettle to more Waggih Pranks. Do not we daily ee, that the Lowet Fluttering Dogrell hall with as great an aurance perch under a Noble Umbrage, as the Highet Soarer in Heroick Flights? The Carrion Crow hall apire to Build in the Cedar's Top, and the Noble Eagle can pretend to no more. This Hereditary Liberty allowed; as alo, That all Modety
is directly againt the Rules of our Order, and the Charter of our Company; And that thee Cogent Poetical Reaons being maturely weighed, may, I hope, Warrant my Obedience to Custome, and Apologize for a Troubleome and Impertinent Dedication; to uffer in which Cae will be for me much more tolerable, than by my omitting o Neceary a Ceremony, provoke a Revengeful and Offended Brotherhood, that will auredly Damn me by a Univeral Conent, for preuming to hope for Salvation, and to Stand and Fall by my own Merits, without praying the Aitance of an able Patron, according to the Laudable Custome.

As for this Tenth Satyr of Juvenal, by All approved for the Gravet, and mot Phyloophical, both for Argument and Matter, of all our Authors, (if his Sene have not lot too much of the Spirit by Transfuion from one Language to another) I hould eteem a Suitable Preent to Your Lordhip, who has Jutly etablihed a Noble and Spotles Reputation from Worthy and Honet Actions: yet have Wiely learnt betimes to take up from a too eager and precipitate Chae of Fame, which Hurries many intemperately through Thick and Thin, violently breaking through the Fences to purue and mater their Game; who often (according to the many Examples in this Satyr decribed) do meet with a Diaterous Concluion, which in them is the Effect of an Immoderate Thirt and Deire of a Name; and does not proceed from the Principles of Steddy Virtue. Your Lordhips
Wier Conideration having denyed Your Self to the Courthip and Blandihments of the World, rather than to give the leat Violence to your Mind and Repoe; chuing rather a Noble Retirement within the Bounds of a Plentiful Fortune; of which few Noble Men can boat a Greater, or have given o Early a Proof of their Knowledge and Skill to ue and manage it to Improvement. Which that Your Lordhip may live Long to enjoy with all Happines and Honour, is the Contant Wih of,

closer.signed: Your Lordhips Mot Devoted, Humble Servant, HENRY HIGDEN.

div.head: To my Ingenious Friend, MR. Henry Higden, Eq; On his Tranlation of the Tenth SATYR OF JUVENAL
div.l: THe Grecian Wits, who Satyr firt began,
Were Pleaant Paquins on the Life of Man:
At Mighty Villains, who the State oppret,
They durt not Rail; perhaps, they Laugh'd at leat,
And turn'd 'em out of Office with a Jest.
No Fool could peep abroad, but ready stand
The Drolls, to clap a Bauble in his Hand:
Wie Legilators never yet could draw
A Fopp within the Reach of Common-Law;
For Poture, Dres, Grimace, and Affectation,
Tho' Foes to Sence, are Harmles to the Nation.
Our lat Redres is Dint of Vere to try;
And Satyr is our Court of Chancery.
This Way took Horace to reform an Age
Not Bad enough to need an Author's Rage:
But Yours,Juvenal. who liv'd in more degen'rate Times,
Was forc'd to faten Deep, and woorry Crimes:
Yet You, my Friend, have temper'd him o well,
You make him Smile in pight of all his Zeal:
An Art peculiar to your Self alone,
To joyn the Vertues of Two Stiles in One.
Oh! were your Author's Principle receiv'd,
Half of the lab'ring World wou'd be reliev'd;
For not to Wih, is not to be Deceiv'd!
Revenge wou'd into Charity be chang'd,
Becaue it cots too Dear to be Reveng'd:
It cots our Quiet and Content of Mind;
And when 'tis compas'd, leaves a Sting behind.
Suppoe I had the better End o'th' Staff,
Why hou'd I help th' ill-natur'd World to laugh?
'Tis all alike to them, who gets the Day;
They Love the Spight and Michief of the Fray.
No; I have Cur'd my Self of that Dieae;
Nor will I be provok'd, but when I pleae:
But let me half that Cure to You retore;
You gave the Salve, I laid it to the Sore.
Our kind Relief againt a Rainy Day,
Beyond a Tavern, or a tedious Play;
We take your Book, and laugh our Spleen away.
If all Your Tribe, (too studious of Debate)
Wou'd ceae fale Hopes and Titles to create,
Led by the Rare Example you begun,
Clyents wou'd fail, and Lawyers be undone.

div.head: TO Henry Higden, Eq; On his Tranlation of the Tenth SATYR OF JUVENAL.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: I Know You, and I mut Confes,
From Sence o Celebrated, and o True,
As that which alwaies hines in You;
I cou'd expect no les.
'Tis Great, 'tis Jut, 'tis Noble all!
Right Spirit of the Original;
No catter'd Spark, no glimmering Beams,
As in ome Pieces here, and there,
Through a dark Glade of Duller Numbers gleams.
But 'tis all Fire! all Glittering every where
Grateful Intruction that can never fail,
To Pleae and Charm, even while you Rail.
By Arts thus Gentle and Severe
The Powers Divine firt made their Mortals Wie;
The oft Reproach they did with Reverence bear;
Whi • e they Ador'd the GOD that did Chatize.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Perhaps there may be found ome Carping Wit,
May blame the Meaures of thy Lines,
And cry,—Not o the Roman Poet writ;
Who dret his Satyr in more lofty Rhimes.
But thou for thy Intructer Nature choe,
That firt bet Principle of Poetry;
And to thy Subject didt thy Vere dipoe,
While in Harmonious Union both agree.
Had the Great Bard thy Properer Numbers view'd,
He wou'd have lay'd his tiff Heroicks by,
And this more Gay, more Airy Path puru'd,
That o much better leads to Ralliery.
Wit is no more than Nature well expret;
And He fatigues and toyles in vain
With Rigid Labours, breaks his Brain,
That has Familiar Thought in lofty Numbers dret.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: True to his Sene and to his Charming Wit,
Thou every where hat kept an equal Pace:
All his Brisk Turns exactly hit,
Jutly maintain'd his Humour and his Grace:
And with the Language hat not chang'd the Face:
Great Juvenal in every Line,
True Roman till o're all does hine;
But in the Brittih Garb appears mot fine.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Long did the Learned Author earch to find
The Vice and Vanity of Humane-kind:
Long he oberv'd, nor did oberve in vain;
In every differing Humour found
Even there where Virtue did abound,
Some mortal Frailties reign.
Philoophers he aw were Proud
Of dull-affected Poverty.
Senators cringing to the Crowd
For trifling Popularity.
The Judge Reviles the Criminal at Bar.
And now becaue old Ages Ice
Has chill'd the Ardour of his willing Vice
Snarles at thoe Youthful Follies which he cannot hare.
From the vain-keeping 'Squire and Cully'd Lord;
The fawning Courtier, States-man's Broken Word:
Down to the flattering, Jilting Curtizan;
And the more faithles couzening Citizen.
The Tricks of Court and State to him were known;
And all the Vices veil'd beneath the Gown:
From the Sharp Pulpit to the Blunted Stall,
He knew, and gently did reproach them all.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: If Rome, that kept the leer World in awe,
Wanted a Juvenal to give them Law,
How much more we, who tockt with Knave and Fool,
Have turn'd the Nation into Ridicule.
The dire Contagion preads to each degree
Of Wild Debauchery.
The mad Infected Youth make hate
To lay their Fortunes, Health, and Reaon wate:
The Fop, a tamer ort of Tool,
Who drees, talks, and loves, by Rule;
Has long for a Fine Peron pat.
Block-heads will pas for Wits, and Write,
And ome for Brave, who ne'r could Fight.
Women for Chate, whoe knack of Cant
Boats of the Virtues that they want:
Cry Faugh—at Words and Actions Innocent,
And make that naughty that was never meant:
That vain-affected Hypocrite hall be
In Satyr ham'd to Honet Sene by Thee.
'Tis Thou, our Englih Juvenal, alone,
To whom all Vice, and every Vertue's known:
Thou that like Judah's King through all hat pat,
And found that all's but Vanity at lat;
'Tis you alone the Dicipline can ue,
Who dare at once be bold, evere, and kind;
Soften rough Satyr with thy gentler Mue,
And force a Bluh at leat, where you can't change the Mind.

div.head: TO H. HIGDEN, Eq; On his Modern Way of Tranlating JUVENAL'S Tenth SATYR.
div.l: IF Poets without Fiction in Applaue
Of their lov'd Mue peak Truth in their own Caue;
And Wit to Favourites gives a Lawful Claim,
To be Inroll'd in Deathles Books of Fame.
Howe'er the Rest of the fam'd Siters thrive,
And happily to Time's lat Sand urvive,
Satyr alone finds a Hard Task to live.
Even half a Key in th' highet Flights of Glory,
nlocks whole Volumes of Heroick Story.
Vertue in Robes of Lating Dye array'd,
Is down even to Remotet Time convey'd.
Great Deeds are Read o Plain, and poke o loud,
Her bright Divinity breaks through the Cloud.
No Antique Garb can againt Worth prevail;
Alcides truts with Club and Lyons Tayl;
And Be • s looks Great in Ruff and Farthingale.
Thus whilt Heroicks their Great Theams diplay,
Stalking abroad in Fields and open Day:
Remarking Satyr mut to Coverts creep,
Pry in cloe Grot • s, and obcure Cloets peep.
They Copy by o weak and faint a Light;
Vice is their Theam, in Maquerade they Write,
And lyly walk in gloomy Scenes of Night;
Thus whilt the warm Intrigue is jut found out
And the freh Calumny is dealt about,
Murmur'd and buz'd through all the Tickled Rout:
Oh! with what Lawrel Wreaths is Satyr Crown'd!
How ravihing the mart Iambicks ound!
But when the Grin, the Sneer, and Jest is pat,
(Malice that runs o wift, and tires as fat)
Poor Satyr then, the Nine Days Wonder done,
Strait lies Neglected, and Forgot as oon:
With its own Parent, Scandal, does expire;
The generous on of an Ignoble Sire.
The Poinant Gall that holds Authentick Text
This Age, is damn'd t' Apocrypha the next.
The Flowry Banks our pleaed Forefathers knew,
O'regrown by Time, we a Rude Labyrinth view,
Where Commentators groap without a Clue.
Whilt Satyr detined to o Harh a Doom,
Must undergo uch Hardhip ev'n at Home;
Alas! what mut it uffer when it walks
Abroad, and in a Forreign Language talks!
Where Loads of Dros the precious Oar enfold,
Skilful mut th' Artist be t' Extract the Gold;
One practied to the World and Mues Laws,
And well acquainted with the Face he draws.
Satyr to Trace at Heels, and poorly Line
For Line Tranlate, is uch a weak Deign,
Does even the Marks of Life, and Spirit want,
A Jargon wore than a Fanatick Cant:
A Wie Attempt, and Jutify'd by none
But ome Enthuiat Prophet of their own.
Thy Pencil corns a Portraicture o faint:
Thou animate't what uch dead Colours paint:
You Naturalize the Author you Tranlate,
And Claick Roman dres in Modern State.
Sprightly and Gay he makes his Viit here;
Dret Al-a-mode, and peaks en Cavalier.
Great Juvenal's Wit, who in an Englih Scene,
By Time's long Rut at bet had pointles been,
Thou grind't to a New Edge, to out more keen.
From Letts and Rubbih clear't the craggy Shore,
And driv'st thy own Triumphant Chariot o're.
His ditant Heat does by thy Labour burn,
And Rear thy Phenix from his Spicey rne.

div.head: THE PREFACE TO THE READER.
div.p: I Did not think to have given you or my elf this Trouble, reolving what I had aid before my Thirteenth Satyr hould have erved the Turn: But ince my Friend Mr. Shadwell, before his late Ingenious Tranlation, has taken ome notice of this Eay of mine, I could not in good Manners, but make his Civility a Return in Print.

This Englih Eay of mine was Perfect, and Licened above a Year ince, as intended to have been Printed in lat Trinity Term was Twelve-month, but was by ome Accident prevented. In the following Vacation Mr. Shadwell did me the Favour to perue it, keeping it for a coniderable Time by him: At the Return he told me, He had a mind to Tranlate it for his Diverion, as liking the Author and Subject; which has taken o good Effect, that I perceive the Younger Brother has by the Common-Mother the Pres outtript the Elder, and lurch'd him of the Bleing: Which I hall not much bewail, ince I had not et my Heart upon it: Nor will I blame his Hate to Chriten his Own Child firt, which is but the way of the World. But I thought it very hard, that his Fondnes to his own way, hould make him (in crying up his own) fall o everely upon all others; proclaiming his own for an Exact and Standard Tranlation, cloe to the Words and Sence of the Author, which mut be o, let it hould happen, (as he ays it does in all Paraphraes) That the Sene and Spirit of the Author be quite deaded and lot; Adding further, that When any preume to Rank and Intermix their ene and thoughts with thoe of the Noble Roman Authors, they look like Patches of homely Woollen on the Richet Silks; this Modern Age producing no Genius like theirs, and therefore their Imaginations mut be Unequal, and hort of the Author's.
A very fine Complement put upon this Age and Nation, which without Vanity have produced Men Eminent and Learned in all Arts and Sciences, and all manner of Learning, urpaing the last preceding Ages, and beyond the pitch of other Nations. And as for Poetry, being the matter in Quetion, I will only intance Mr. Cowley, who perhaps had as great a Genius in all orts of Poetry, both Latin and Englih, as any one of the Ancients: But, it eems, he would Monopolize and Confine the Wit of this Age (like the Caballitical Learning of the Jews) to a Club of his Acquaintance, who (it eems) are no profeed Poets, but choice Spirits, and by much the greatet Wits in England, and o trancending others, that he thinks England never produced the like in any Age.

This frank way of dealing with the World, and impoing his own Fancy for Laws on others, led me to conider how my Friend had gone through with the Irkome drudgery of his Tranlation; and how his Genius had comported with o mean an Imployment, not doubting but he had nicely oberved thoe Rules he had o Magiterially laid down for others, and in Modety had forborn to mingle any Thought of his own with his Noble Roman Author, which might poibly naueate our stomachs like Wine of two tats; preuming he had urpaed the Elaborate Tranlations of Stapleton and Holliday; of which I will not pretend to judge: When upon Perual, I found he had not trictly followed his Author, but made bold to Paraphrae and Embroider his Author's Rich Silken Garment with homely Woollen Patches of his own, I hall intance only in four Veres, being the firt that came to Hand, the two firt taken out of his Son's Tranlation of Cato's Speech, printed before his Tranlation; the later two Veres being in the Firt Page of his Satyr, and printed with a different Character, to denote omething extraordinary.

In Cato's Speech:
Haeremus Cuncti uperis:
which he renders thus:
We all on God, as parts of him, depend;
There does the Mighty Chain begin and end.

Now I would have our nice Tranlator point out where the Author o much as hints any thing of this Mighty Chain; or intruct his tolerable Grammarian where to find it: which Chain mut (like Jacob's Ladder) be Mighty enough to reach from Earth to Heaven: Of which I can find no more in our Author, than of a Cable or Sheet-Anchor. Beides, it will allow of a Dipute, whether God has any Parts.

The other Intance is in the Firt Page of his Satyr:
Cantabit vacuus coram latrone viator.
Which he Tranlates thus:
While the Poor man void of all Precious things,
In company of Thieves, joggs on and ings.

Which Mr. Holliday has more truly and comprehenively tranlated in One Vere, thus:
Before the Thief, who travels empty, Sings.

There was no neceity the Authors Traveller hould be a Poor Man; for if he had nothing of Value about him, he might ing without Fear, though he were Wealthy at home: And if we allow him a Poor Man we might gues he was Void of all Precious things. Which word Void is very eldome ued in the ence there intended: May be the Poor Man voided his precious Stones long before he came into the Thieves Company, that the Capon might ing the weeter in his Journey. Beides, I can perceive nothing in the Author that warrants that Heroick Phrae, (joggs on.) The Author's meaning is, that the empty Traveller having no caue of fear, might ing before the Thief: Yet there is no neceity he hould Jog on in Company of Thieves, who perhaps had other Deigns on foot, than to liten to his Melody. But I uppoe, the next time he will mend his Hand, and not brew and dah his Vere, till 'tis like Wine of two lats, that when we have pallated the New, we hall have no reaon to ay the Old is better. Let Milo in the Satyr be an Example to him, not to preume too much on his own trength, depiing others, let being wedged in a trap of his own making, he become a Prey to the merciles Criticks.

And thus much I thought my elf obliged to ay upon this occaion, ince the Tranlator was not only content tyly to top his Tranlation upon his Friend; but by way of Anticipation, would arrogantly cry down all but his own Tranlation.

I hould now ay omething for this Eay of mine, which I never deigned for a just Tranlation, though I have alwaies kept the Author in my Eye, and not willingly rambled too far from him, (except in the Decription of the Praetor and his Equipage) which was too tubborn to work into my Vere, endeavouring to make his ence, Englih, and uch as is now currant; All Satyr having a trong tate of the Humour and particular Hints of the Times wherein they were writ, which is indeed the Life and Beauty of Satyr. And I am the more confirmed in the Opinion of my way, ince I have read a Verbal Tranlation, done by o able a hand as Mr. Shadwell's. In mine I have rather imitated that Admirable Tranlation of Quevedo, that gives Life and Spirit to his Author, by making him Englih, in a Modih and Familiar way, which I hope you will approve of, and excue

I have in the End of the Book Printed a New Tranlation of Cato's Speech in Lucan, done, and ent me by an unknown Hand, though in the Printing it has met with ome alterations: For which, I beg the Author's Pardon; ubmitting his Poem and my Satyr as Foyls to Mr. Shadwell's; being deirous to Play one Fragment againt another.

div.head: JUVENAL's TENTH SATYR, Made Englih.
div.l: SUrvey Mankind, (1) muter the Herd
From moothet Chin to deepet Beard;
Search every Climate, view each Nation,
from lowet to the highet Station;
From Eatern to the Wetern Indies,
From frozen Poles to'th Lyne that indges:
Scarce will you find one Mortal Wight
Knows Good from Ill, or Wrong from Right,

note.l: OMNIBUS. Tanta et humanae mentis coecitas, ut in toto orbe vix ab ortu Solis uque ad occaum, pauciimi inveniantur, qui vera bona, a malis point dicernere, vel quid it ecundum rationem fugiendum quid petendum. Omnibus in terris quae unt aGADIEUS. Inula nunc Cadiz vocata, in itore Hi panico ita, ultra fretum olim Herculeum dictum, hodie angutiae de Gibralter; hic Poetae Herculem duas Columnas tatuie volunt: Extremum occidentem credebant antiqui unde Elogium Herculis Columnis ineriptum. NE PLUS ULTRA. Gadibus uque
AuroramGANGEM. Nobiliimum Indiae orientalis Fluvium. & Gangem, pauci dignocere pount
VERA BONA. Quae animi tantum unt, uti Virtus, Jutitia, & vitae integritas, quae fracta Nave cum nudo Poeore enatare point. Vera bona,

div.l: 'Caue clouds of Lut and Paion blind
And while they Combat in our heart,
Our Fondnes crowns the conqu'ring part.
What is the thing under the Sun,
That we with Reaon eek or hun?
Or Jutly by our Judgment weigh'd,
Should make us fond of, or afraid?
What 'ere is luckily begun
Brings ure Repentance at long-run.
The ditant Object loomeing great,A term of Art at Sea, ignifying the appearance of a Veel at a ditance
Poet, proves oft an empty Cheat;
And he who wins the wih't for prize
A trouble often dearly buyes.

note.l: —a'que illis multum divera, remota

div.l: Some for their Family importune
And beg their ruin for a Fortune.
The Courteous Gods granting their Prayers,
Have intayl'd Cures on their Heirs.
Of Wizards ome inquire their doom
Greedy to know Events to come
And by their over Caution run
On the ame Fate they trove to hun:
Some have petition'd to be great
And eminent in Church and State;
This in the Warrs a famous Leader,
T'other at Bar a cunning Pleader,
The Caue on either ide enure yee,
By dint of noye tun Judge and Jury:

note.l: Evertere domus totas opt antibus ipis
Dij faciles: nocitura Toga, nocitura a petuntur

Militia.EVERTERE: Dij prompti nimis & faciles ad largiendum, & obequendum votis hominum importunis, dum dant hominibus mala & noxia petentibus totas domus & familias fuas perdiderunt, etiam optantibus ipis dominis. torrensTORRENS: Eloquentia abundans, & Torrentis intar fluens, multis exitium tulit, ut Ciceroni & Demotheni: ut infra v. 1140. dicendi copia multis,

div.l: And if the buines won't bear water
Then banter and perplex the matter.
But their obtrep'rous Eloquence
Has fail'd ev'n in their own defence;
And aving others by Ha •• anguing
Have brought themelves at lat to hanging.
(2) Milo preuming on his trength
Caus'd his own detiny at length.
The greedy care of heaping Wealth
Damns many a Soul and ruins Health,
And in an Apoplectick Fitt
Sinks them down right into the pitt.
How many Uptarts crept from low
Condition, vat poeions how?

note.l: Et ua mortifera et Facundia. Viribus ille
Confius periit admirandique lacertis.

Sed pluresNIMIA: Cura in divitiis accumulandis trangulat, opri • it uffocat, dum omni ratione laborant, ut uus cenus tanto excedat aliorum cenus, quanto balaena Britanica exuperat delphinam mole. nimia conget a pccunia cura
Strangulat, & cuncta exuperans patrimonia cenus
Quanto delphinis balaena Britanica major.

div.l: Whoe Etate's audit o immene
Exceeds all Prodigal Expence.
With which compare that Spot of Earth,
To which thee Muhroms owe their Birth:
Their Mannours to Dads Cottage how,
As Greenland Whales to Dolphins do.
In (3) Neroe's Plotting dimal times
Riches were judg'd ufficient Crimes.
Firt wear them Traytors to the State,
Then for their pains hare their Etate.
Fat forfeitures their Toyles reward:
Poor Rogues may pas without regard.
Some are hook'd in for Sene and Wit,
And ome Condemn'd for want of it.

note.l:
Temporibus diris igitur, juuque
NERONIS: Nero undique occaione quaeita, divitum opibus inidiabatur & diris illis & Tyranicis temporibus Imperatore jubente, tota Cohors militum percuorum clauit Longinum & Senecae praedivitis hortos, et aedes divitum Lateranorum ut divitias uas cum vita adimeret. Exempla illa funeta demontrant, divitias multis exitiales faie.
LATERANORUM. Plautii Laterani quem interici etiam juit Nero. Neronis,
Longinum, et magnos Senecae praedivitis hortos
Clauit, et Egregias Lateranorum obidet aedes
Tota cohors.

div.l: The over-rich Longinus (4) dyes:
His bright heaps daz'led Envious eyes.
Neither could deep Philoophy,
Widome, deert, or Piety
Rich Seneca (5) from his Pupil ave,
'Tis fit he end him to a Grave,
And then reume the wealth he gave.
The Guards the Pallaces beet,
For Noble Game they pitch their net:
While from Alarms and Pangs of fear,
Securely leeps the Cottager.
If you by night hall happen late,
To Travail with a Charge of Plate;
With watchful eyes and panting heart,
Surpriz'd, each Object makes you Start:

note.l: RARUS. Miles vel perouor juu Neronis Ratus in pauperuin caulas & caenacula venit, ut eos poliet vel trucidet. Rarus venit in canacula miles.
Panca licet portes argenti vacula puri,

Nocte iter ingreus, gladium contum
que tiniebis:

div.l: While Rack'd with doubts, oppret with fear,
Each Buh does an arm'd Thief appear:
A haken reed will Terrour Strike,
Mitaken for a brandih'd Pike.
Before the Thief, the empty Clown
Sings unconcern'd and Travailes on.
With warm Petitions mot men ply
The Gods, their Baggs may multiply;
That riches may grow high and ranck
Out welling others in the Bank.
But from plain wood and earthen Cupps,
No poyon'd draught the Peaant upps.
Of the Gold Goblet take thou care,
When parkling wine's pic'd by thy heir:
Et motae ad Lunam trepidabis arundinis umbram.

note.l: CANTABIT: Securo animo et, cui nihil et, nihil auerri potet; illis autem Maxime timendum quibus Maximae divitiae. Gantabit vacuus coram latrone viator.
Prima fere vota, & cunctis notiima Templis
Divitiae, crecant ut cpes, ut maxima toto
Notra it arcaFORO: Trajano cil ubi Senatores et ditiores arcas habebant, in quibus argentum & pecuniam tutius diponebant. foro. Sed nulla aconita bibuntur
Fictilibus: tunc illa time, cum pocula umes
Gemmata & latoSENTINUM vinum entinum flammei erat coloris in auratis poculis. entinum ardebit in auro.

div.l: Then who can blame that brace of Wiemen
That did in diffring moods depie men:
Th' old merry Lad aunters the Streets,
And laughs, and drolls at all he meets:
For Patime rallys, flouts, and fools 'em,
Shamms, banters, mimicks, ridicules 'em.
The other Sage in maudling wie,
Their Errors mourns with weeping Eyes.
Dull Fools with eae can grin and neere,
And Buffoons flout with awcy jeere.
What owrce could contant Tears upply,
To feed the luces of each Eye!
Or t'others merry humour make,
His pleen continually to hake?

note.l: Jamne igitur laudas quod de apientibusALTER. Democritum Abdecritam philoophum intellige qui emper tultitias & Ineptias hominum ridebat. alter
Ridebat, quoties de limite moverat unum
Pretulerat que • edem; Flebat contrariusALTER. Heraclitus Epheius notatur qui emper hominum dementiam et mierias deflebat. alter:

l.U: ed facilis cuivis rigidi cenura cachinni.

note.l: Mirandum et unde ille oculis uffecerit Humor.
Perpetuo riu pulmenem agitare olebat
Democritus—

div.l: Since the rude Thracian in his City
Ne're aw proceion halfo pretty,
As modern Pageantry and State
Does on our City-Triumphs wait;
Than which no Interlude is gayer,
Whilt Sword and Cap uher the Mayor;
A Cap that does with Heads dipene
Without regard of Brains or Sene:
And whoe myterious Power tranlates
Mechanick Furs to Potentates,
From weighing Plumbs, to ballance States.
So Mayor and Aldermen from Stalls
Wier than PopeL. Ch. J. Scroggs at Jeuits Tryal. and Cardinals,

note.l: —quanquam non eent rbibus illis
PRAETEXTA, &c. Poeta hic enumerat Ornamenta Regalia & caetera inignia Romani Praetoris. Praetexta, & trabeae, faces, lectica, Tribunal.
Quid i vidiet Praetorem Curribus altis
Extantem et medio ublimem in Pulvere Circi
In Tunica Jovis,

div.l: From Shop to Bench with inpired Noddle
The Body Politick does waddle;
Where Preident mute Judge hears Caue
That Statute never read nor Laws.
So Rablais Gown conveys his pirit
To all ucceeding Quacks that wear it.
Thus Furs, more proud than Ermyn, muter,
Gilt Jack-Chains give the Faction Luter;
Whilt the whole Livery attend,
Banners and Trophies without end:
Of honour'd Guets a Cavalcade
Whoe Friendhip by the Treat is made;

note.l: —&PICTAE: in palmata trabea, id et in picta & triumphali toga quam ex templo Jovis fumptam induebant. pictae Sarrana ferentem
Ex humerisAULAEA Sarrana, atyrice io Dictum, araiana quai purpurea & Aulaea Regia. Aulaea Togae, magnaeque coronae.
Tantum orbem, quanto cervix non ufficit ulla?
Quippe tenet udans bancPUBLICUS. Servus qui triumphantibus à tergo in eodem curru adtabat ut coronam illam auream immeni ponderis & amplitudmis uftneret. publicus, & ibi conul
Ne placeat, curru ervus portatur eodem.
Da nunc & volucrem, ceptro quae urgit eburno,
Illinc cornicines, hinc praecedentia longi
Agminis officia, & niveos ad frena Quirites,
Deoa in loculis quos portula fecit amicos.

div.l: By flowing Bowls and City Cutard
T'huzzahs and Io Paeans fluter'd.
Thus haughty Mayor without a Charter
Looks big, as if intall'd 'oth' Garter:
Their Leaden Sword and Mace may wagger;
But the wie State ecur'd their Dagger.
For Children and unskilful fools
Cut their own fingers with edg'd-tools.
Could he in ober honet times
With harp conceit tax petty crimes!
And every where amongt the rout
Find follyes for his Wit to flout:
Which, proves that Goatham and groe Clymes
Produce prodigious Wits ometimes.

note.l: TUNC. Emphatice dictum, quum cilicet homines (vivente Democr • to) prudenter & longe rectius vitas uas contituebant; quanto magis notro tempore hominum vanitates rideret. Tunc qucque materiam rius invenit ad omneis
Occurus hominum—

div.l: The Joys and fears of the vain crowd,
And whimp'ring tears hee'd jeer aloud;
Wiely ecure, Fortune deride
By Foppih Mortals Deify'd;
Bid her behang'd, and laugh at Fate
When threatned at the highet rate;
Whilt Fools for vain and harmful things
Pour out their Prayers and Off'rings,
Fating Petitions on the (7) Knees
Of their regardles Deityes.
For place and power how many men vy
Procuring mortal Hate and Envy;

note.l: —cujus prudentia montrat
Summos poe viros, & magna exempla daturos
VERVECUM PATRIA: vervex et convitium hominis implicis & rudis, ic Plautus, Ain' vero Vervecum Caput, anglice Sheeps-Head. Vervex et aries catratus. Vervecum in patria, craoque ub aere naci.
Ridebat curas, nec non & gaudia vulgi:

Interdum & lachrymas, cumFORTUNAE: nam cum Fortuna minitaretur mali al quod Democrito, ille in contemptu mandaret fortunae laqueum, in ipius upendium, protendens medium infamem digitum, reliquis digitis contractis, quae contumelia indicabat ignominioum Cinaedum vel Scortum. fortunae ipe minaci
Mandaret laqueum, mediumque otenderet unguem.
Ergo upervacua aut ibi pernitioa petuntur,
Propter quae fas etGENUA: Olim concepta vota in tabulis concripta Deorum genibus cera obignata affixerunt. genua incerare Deorum.
Quodam praecipitat ubjecta potentia magnae—Invidiae,

div.l: Heralds long winded Titles ound
Which the vain owners oft confound.
Down go their Statues in digrace;
The Party hangs up in the place.
In rage they break Chariot triumphant,
Becaue a Knave firt et his rump ont:
Poor Hores uffer for no fau't
Unles by bungling work-men wrought.
The Founders Fournace grows red hot,
Sejanus (8) Statue goes to pot:
That Head lately ador'd, and reckond
In all the Univere the Second,
Melted new forms and hapes aumes,
Of Pipots, Frying-pans, and Spoons:

note.l: —mergit longa at que inignis honorum

PAGINA: Tabula aenaea ima. ginibus affixa quae honorum gradus continebat. Pagina;DESCENDUNT: Statuae damnatorum tyranidis, laefae Majetatis, vel gravis alicujus criminis, nomina eorum eradibantur fatis, Statuae frangebantur idque decreto Magitratus, vel furore populi, laqueos altioribus Statuis olebant injicere atque ita detrahere. decendunt Statuae retemque equuntur.
Ipas deindeROTAS: Currus Triumphale • , Statuas equetres, equos aenaeos. rot as bigarum impacta ecuris
Caedit, & immeritis franguntur crura Caballis.

Jam stridentIGNES: quibus unduntur & liquuntur Statuae, & ardet, & liquecit caput Statuae Sejani, nuper in tanto honore habitum, fuerat enim perpetuus Collega Tibe • ii Imperatoris eique ecundi honores habebantur. ignes, jam follibus at que caminis
Ardet adoratum populo caput, & crepat ingens
Sejanus: deinde ex acie toto orbe ecunda
Fiunt urceoli, pelves, artago, patellae.

div.l: The Crowd o'rejoy'd that Caear's living
Petition for a new thankgiving.
How the bae Rout inult to ee
Sejanus dragg'd to Detiny!
Cryes one, that fellow I ne're brook'd,
How down and hangingly he look'd!
What blobber lips the racal hew'd?
I told you hee'd ne're come to good.
But what's his Crime, or how detected?
That Quetion wholly is neglected:
What Evidence or Judges it?
Phaw, waw, that matters not a whit?
When o apparent was his Crime,
A formal proces would loe time.

note.l: PONE: quod fieri olitum in laetitia Publica, in qua frondibus domus ornabantur. Pone domi lauresDUC: Cretatum (i. e.) candidum bovem quem Jovi Capitolino ex triumphantium more immoles; in gratiarum actionem; Superis enim candidas victimas immolabant, Inferis nigras. duc in Capitolia magnum
Creta • mque bovem:SEJANUS: qui paulo ante alios in Triumphum ducebat, jam ipe unco trahitur ad upplicium ad ealas Gemonias juxta Tybrim al • is pectaculum exhibiturus. Sejanus ducitur unco

Specta • dus:GAUDENT OMNES ejus interitu, ne quis illi amicus videretur. gaudent omnes.QUAE LABRA haec inter e populus in horas mobilis, a pectaculo tam triti reverus; occio Sejano inultans. quae labra? quis illi

Vultus crat?NUNQUAM: Hic dialogus brevis incipiens cum occupatione, quai dicat, ego quidem nunquam amavi Sejanum, ed tamen libenter cirem, ub quo crimine ceciderit, aut quo tete Imperator probat Sejanum ibi truxie inidias. nunquam (i quid mihi credis) amavi
Hunc hominem. ed quocecidit ub crimine? quinam
Delator? quibus Indicibus, quo tete probavit?
NIL HORUM repondens alter, fatetur e nil horum cire quae in judicio Capitali fieri olebant, ed verboa & grandis epitola • enit à Capreis qua Imperator Sejanum ee reum demontravit. Nil horum—

div.l: Long letters were from (9) Capra ent
By Caear to the Parliament,
With orders not to be diputed,
The Traytor hould be executed.
'Tis very well, th'other reply'd
Your ervant Sir, I'me atisfy'd.
What thought the Mobile the while?
Nothing; tame animals they mile:
Contentedly drive with the Tyde
And alwayes hate the uffering ide.
Had Fortune own'd Sejanus part,
And with ucces had crown'd his art:
And our young States-man had the hap
To've ta'ne the old (10) Fox in his trap:

note.l: —verboa & grandis epistola venit
A Capreis:BENE: repondet primus interrogator, e jam omnem rem tenere & intelligere. bene habet, nil plus interrogo; ed quid
Turbaremi? equitur fortunam, ut emper, & odit

Damnatos. idem populus, iNURTIA: fortuna Dea Thucorum. enus et, i Sejanus Thucus fortuna Dea patriae avente Tiberium oppreiet, Populus Romanus Sejanum in Tiberii locum aumpiet, eumque imperatorem Augutum falutaet. Nurtia Tuco
Faviet, i opprea foret ecura enectus—Principis,

div.l: Then our uccesful Favorite
The World had own'd to've been i'th' right:
The fawning Rabble had that hour
Saluted him their Emperour.
Poor Roman fools ince ancient date
Can Sell no voices in the State;
Now freed from Care, and living idle
Are taught to bite upon the Bridle.
Who once Dictators, Conuls, choe,
And did all Offices dipoe,
Pas now ingloriouly their dayes,
And meanly beg for Bread and Playes.
'Tis aid Warrants are out to eie
Many and great Accomplices.

note.l: —hac ipa Scjanum diceret hora

Augutum, jam pridemEXQUO: A tempore Monarchiae Julii Caearis, ex quo imperatores ee ceperunt; nos Romani per uffragia quae plerunque venalia fuerunt non eligimus Magitratus, nec vendimus diveris candidatis competitoribus. ex quo uffragia nulli

VendimusEFFUGIT Populus Romanus curas Electionis & Comitiorum, quippe Imperatores Conulum comitia ad e transtulere, exemplo Julii Caearis. effugit curas.NAM P. R. Qui per uffragia dabat Imperium, dictaturam, Conulatum, Praeturam, Legiones, Belli praefecturam omnia officia & honores nunc optant cum anxietate nam qui dabat olim
Imperium, faces, legiones, omnia, nunc e
Continet, at que duas tantum res anxius optat
Panem ad victum, & voluptatem è ludis Circenibus. Panem, & Circenes.PERITUROS: Alter Populi paventis introducitur dialogimus. perituros audio multos.

div.l: Likely; the Prince his Rage does burn as
Outragiouly as fire in Furnace.
At Mars his Shrine I met Brutidius
With ghatly looks, all pale, and hideous,
Since the ill-manag'd Plot took vent
His looks declare his dicontent,
As if for game ill play'd he meant,
Like Ajax to anticipate
With his own hands his ling'ring Fate.
But to wipe off upition
On our part, let's to Tyber run;
While on the Banck the Corps does ly
Trample on Caears Enemy.

note.l: Nil dubium: magna etFORNACULA: Ira in Pectore Tiberii aetuante. vel Fornacula ad exurendos malos & proditores. fornacula: pallidulus mi

BRUTIDIUS: Vereor ne Brutidius amicus meus, quem modo conveni pallentem ad Martis aram; ex male concio animo, vel metu principis, quod Amicus & Conpirator cum Sejano e interficiat icut Ajax. Brutidius mens ad Martis fuit obvius aram.
Quem timeo, victus ne paenas exigat Ajax,
t male defenus! curramus praecipites, et,
Dum jacet in ripa calcemus CaearisHOSTEM: Sejani Cadaver. hotem.

div.l: But 'twill do wiely our whole Crew
Of Servants hould the action veiw;
That Friends, and Foes may tetify
How we abhor diloyalty.
The murm'ring vulgar at this rate
Did of the fal'n Sejanus prate:
Would you on thee Conditions, Sir,
Be Favourite and Prime-Miniter,
As was Sejanus? Stand Poet
Of Honours, Power and Interet;
Dipoe upream Commands at will,
Promote, digrace, preerve, or kill:
Be guardian to a careles King
Who in all pleaures takes his wing:

note.l: SedVIDEANT SERVI ne quis eorum tanquam Sejano aventes accuet. videant ervi, ne quis neget, & pavidum in jus
Cervice obtricta dominum trahat: hi ermones
Tunc de Sejano, eoreta haec murmura vulgi.
Vis ne alutari icut Sejanus? habere
Tantundom? atque illi ummas donoereCURULES: Magitratus urbanos, ellis Curulibus in Curiam vehi & ex iis jura dare olebant Magitratus. Curuleis?

Illum exercitibus praeponere?TUTOR: Vicarius Imperatoris ee dum in anguta Caprearum Inula in eceu otium & vitam libidinoam agit, cum Chaldeis Mathematicis & Fatidicis quibus mire deditus erat Tiberius. tutor haberi
Principis Auguta Caprearum in rupe edentis
Cum grege Chaldeo?—

div.l: Cloyt'red in Bawdy Grots and Cellers,
With Pimps, Buffoones, and Fortune-Tellers.
Have Foot and Hore-Guards, the Command
Of Armys both by Sea and Land.
Why not? Though Good-men would not kill,
Yet in their pow'r they'd have it till:
What Pleaure can o tickle ene;
Sharp pains and Grief to recompene,
What happy or exalted State,
But is o're ballanc'd by Ill Fate?
Would not you rather ask in Prayer,
To be ome Petty Country Mayor:
There domineer, and when your Pleaur's,
Condemn light weights, & break fale meaures.

note.l: —VIS CERTE: cio te velle primipilatum vel legionis praefecturam Pila ponitur pro peditibus pilis munitis. vis certe pila, Cohortes,
EGREGIOS EQUITES equitum dometicorum Magiterium. Egregios equites, etCASTRA DOMESTICA: Praetoriana quae primus ad muros Romae pouit Sejanus. catra dometica, quid ni
Haec cupias? et qui nolunt occidere quenquam
Poe volunt. Sed quae praeclara et propera tanti,
t rebus laetis par it menura malorum?
Hujus qui trahiturPRAETEXTAM fummum imperium cum Sejaui periculo et upplicio. praetextam umere mavis,

An Fidenarum Gabiorum
que eePOTESTAS an in obcura Villa Aelilem vel Magitratum cum ecura tranquillitate. Potetas?
Et de menuris jus dicere, vaa minora
Frangere pannous vacuis aedilisULUBRIS: vel Aedilis in vacuo et de erto Volcorum oppido. lubris.

div.l: Though meanly clad in afe etate
Then chooe Sejanus Robes and Fate.
Sejanus then we mut conclude
Courting his Bane, mitook the Good.
For he who from a mean etate
Vat Honours did accumulate,
And endles Riches, which enable
To build his Fortune high as Babel,
And brav'd the World; by weight too large
Did th' high pil'd Storyes overcharge:
Whence hockt with torms the reeling weight
The owner did precipitate,
And Signaliz'd Ambitions Fate.

note.l: ERGO: Repetit propoitionem & concludit ipum Sejanum vera bona ignorae, quai dicat, contatergo Sejanum dum honores &c. appetiit nihil boni petiie, ed in altum & ummum honorum cacumen acendie, ut altius & profundius rueret. Claudianus. Ergo quid optandum foret ignorae fateris
Sejanum. nam qui nimios optabat honores,

Et nimias pocebat opes,NUMEROSA: Sibi ipi numeroas & multiplices contignationes & tabulata in excelo honorum fatigio exaedificabat, unde potea deturbatus per ingens atque immane praecipitium violenta ruina decideret. numero a parab at
Excelae turris tabulata, unde altior e • t
Caus, & impulae praeceps immane ruinae.
• Lapu graviore ruant, tolluntur in altum.

div.l: Craus and Pompeys fate of old
The truth of this ure Maxime told:
And his who firt bow'd Romes Stiff neck,
And made the World obey his beck,
By Subtil ways and arts apir'd
And Sov'reign way at length accquir'd;
While the Malignant Heavens decreed,
His own deires hould make him bleed;
Tyrants with ome untimely end
To Proerpines black Court decend.
The Novice in his Accidence,
Dares pray his Wit and Eloquence
May Rival Roman Cicero's (11) fame
And Greek Demothenes (12) high name.

note.l: QuidCRASSOS: Marcum Craum patrem a Surena Legato Parthorum rege devictum; ejuque filios a Parthis & Caearianis occios. Craos, quidPOMPEIOS: Pompeium magnum cum duobus filiis a Caearianis trucidatos. Pompeios evertit?ET ILLUM: Julium Caearem perpetuum Dictatorem intelligit, qui Quirites (i. e.) cives Romanos domitos deduxit ad ua flagra (i. e.) imperium abolutum; imminuta imo amia libertate, ille a Bruto, Caio, & reliquis conjuratoribus in Senatu, 23. vulneribus confous periit. & illum,
Ad ua qui domitos deduxit flagra Quirites?
Summus nempe locus nulla non arte petitus,
Magnaque numinibus vota exandita malignis.
AD GENERUM CERERIS: (i. e.) ad Plutonem Proerpinae filiae Cereris maritum, pauci Tyranni decendunt morte non cruenta. Ad generum Cereris ine caede, & vulnere pa •• i
Decendunt Reges, & icca morte Tyranni.
ELOQUIUM: Puer elementarius qui literis initiatur, quem ervus Caparius deducit ad cholam & reducit pauculos erens libros. Eloquium & famam Demothenis & Ciccronis

Incipit optare, & totisQUINQUATRIEUS: (i. e.) in etis Minervae apientiae praeidis quae quinque diebus celebrantu • ; exoptat eloquentiam Demothenis & Ciceronis. alii putant hoc de Paedagogo non de Dicipulo dictum. Quinquatribus optat,
Quisquis adhuc uno partam colit ae Minervam,
Quem equitur cutos angutae vernula capae.

div.l: Yet to both thee, their welling vein
Of wit and fancy prov'd their bane;
The Fatal caue that Forfeited,
The Ciceronian hands and head.
No pleading dunce's jobber noule,
Revenge e're doom'd hould grace a Pole.
O happy Romes ecure Etate,
Where I was fortunate innate;Wherein the Tranlator imitates the gingle of Cicero's own Vere.
Had happily his Genius choe
To've writ uch inoffenive proe;
His harmles blunt tupidity
Might Antonys Revenge defy;
'Tis afer eneles vere to write,
Than in Philippicks keenly bite.

note.l: Eloquio ed uterque perit orator, utrumque
Largus, et exundans letho dedit ingenii fons,
IngenioMANUS: et Caput Ciceronis abcia affigebantur rotris e quibus in Antonium dixerat. manus et, et cervix caea, nec unquam
Sanguine Cauidici maduerunt rotra puilli.

O FORTUNATAM: verum hinc Ciceronis de oppreu Catalina in uo Conulatu irridet, propter vocem natam natam inepte iteratam, unde Author innuit: i talia inepta carmina Cicero emper cripiet, et tam inepte omnia dixiet ab Antonii gladiis tutus et ecurus evaiet. O fortunatam natam me Conule Romam.
Antonii gladios potuit contemnere i ic
Omnia dixiet: ridenda P • emata malo,

Quam te conpicuae divinaPHILIPPICA orationes Ciceronis in Antonium quas malo omine Philippicas incripit ab iis quas in Philippum regem Macedonia habuit Demothenes. Quae ambobus oratoribus aeque exitiales fuerunt. Philippica famae,
Volveris a prima quae proxima.—

div.l: A violent and ullen fate
Did on th' admir'd Athenian wait;
Whoe manage Mobile's had guided
As with a rein where e're he ided.
Yet born under unlucky Stars
Sqinting untoward and pervere,
Was ent by's warthy blear-ey'd Sire
Betimes from ooty forge and fire,
From making words and martial tools,
To hammer Arguments in Schools.
The Trophies which the vanquih'd field
Do to the glorious Victors yield,
Triumphant Conquerours can bles
With more than humane happines.

note.l: —aevus &ILLUM: Demothenem cujus eloquentia in modum torrentis fluens, regebat & gubernabat totum Theatrum & auditorium plenum civibus Athenienibus: in quo orationes recitare olitus: qui accepto nuntio de Antipatri & Crateri adventu, in Calabriam Thraciae ad aram Neptuni profugit, a cujus ara cum Archias atelles cum abtrahere conaretur, Demothenes veneno quod in calamo habuit hauto interiit. illum
Exitus eripuit, quem mirabantur Athenae
Torrentem & pleni moderantem frena Theatri.
Diis ille adverus genitus, fatoque inistro,
Quem pater ardentis maae fuligine lippus
A carbone, & forcipibus, gladioque parante
Incude, & luteo Vulcano ad rhetora miit.

BELLORUM: tranit jam eloquentia ad glorias laudes ac victorias bellicas, quae tantopere a plurimis appetuntur, & reputantur umma bona & prorus divina ee licet multis exitio fuie demontrat exemplis Annibalis, Alexandri magni, & Xerxis. Lorica, & fracta de caide buccula pendens.
Et currum temone jugum, victaeque triremis
APLUSTRE: Ornamenta navium: Victoriae Navalis ornamenta: Flaggs, Pendants, Streamers, &c. Aplustre, & ummo tritis Captivus in arcu.
Humanis major a bonis creduntur:—

div.l: This Roman, Grecian, and Barbarian, (13)
Spurr'd to acts hazardous and daring,
In weat and blood, pending their dayes
For empty Fame, and fadeing Bayes.
'Tis the immoderate thirt of Fame
Much more than Vertue does inflame:
Which none for wore or better take
But for her dower and trappings ake.
The fond Ambition of a few
Many vat Empires overthrew;
While their Archievements with their dut
They vainly to their Tombtones trut.
For epulchres like bodyes ly
Swallow'd in Deaths obcurity.

div.l: Behold how mall an Urn contains
The mighty Hannibals (14) Remains.
Yet this was he whoe welling mind
To Affrick (15) could not be confin'd;
Though meas'ring that large tract of Land
From Tangier to Niles reaking and:
Thence outhwards to Cape Bon 'Sperance
Negroes and lofty Elephants:
Whence wafting o're the Mid-land Main,
He conquers and poees Spain:
Retles in his ambitious mind,
Italian Conquets are deign'd.
Strong Bars wie Nature did oppoe
The Alps (16) thatcht with eternal Snows:

div.l: His way not craggy Mountain blocks,
With Vinegar (17) he eats through rocks:
Impediments by Nature cat
By art or labour are o're pat,
To Italy he comes at lat;
Where after Towns and Battles won
He crys, Comrades, there's nothing done,
Unles our Conqu'ring Punick Powers
Brake down Romes Gates, level her Towers,
Root up her Pots, and brake her chains,
And knock out all Oppoers Brains:
Whilt our Troops cowr the City thorough
And fix our Standard inA high Street in the City, like Cheap-ide. Saburra.

note.l: DIDUXIT ditraxit, diviit, viam per Alpes apperiens adhibito incendio, & infusò aceto copulos fregit, ut fabulosè cribit Livius. Diduxit copulos, & montem rupit <>
Jam tenet Italiam: tamen ultra <…> ,

ACTUM verba Hannibalis miram regnandi libidinem exprimentis, quibus milites uos hortat Romam ipam perdere, innuens victorias adhinc acquiitas nullius momenti ee, nii Punico milite Romae portas frangeret, ac urbe devicta, vexillum ummum Triumphantem in Saburra nobiliima & altiima urbi • part • collocaret. Actum, inqu't, nihil est, nii <…>
Frangimus, & media vexillum pono <> .

div.l: Oh had you then his Figure een,
With what a rueful Phis and meine,
The Rhod'montado Captain poke,
Doubtles your laughter 'twould provoke!
Some pencil now to paint the form
Of this grum bulk of Huff and Storm;
While Swarthy, meager, and one-ey'd,
He does his Africk Monter ride.
But what Catatrophy of Fate,
Does on our famous Leader wait!
His Conduct's baffled, Army's broke,
Carthage puts on the Roman Yoak:
Whilt Flight and Banihment's his Fate,
His ruin'd Countryes Scorn and Hate:

note.l: O QUALIS FACIES: irridet Poeta vanitatem & deformitatem Annibalis, qui tamen tot & tanta in mente agitabat, quam ridicula facies & igura it, i unoculus dux Getulo alicui Elephanti inidens, in pictura pingueretur. O qualis facies, & quali digna tabella,
Cum Getula Ducem portaret belluaLUSCUM: unoculum alterum amierat vigiliis & palutri caelo dum in Etruriam decenderet. lucum!
Exitus ergo quis et? O gloria! vincitur idem
Nempe, & in exilium praeceps fugit,

div.l: At the Bythinian (18) Tyrants Gate,
The reform'd Fugitive mut wait:
And there for audience uppliant it,
Till the Kings Levè will admit.
Neither the word, nor pear, nor dart,
Could reach that wie undaunted heart,
And decently dipatch that Soul
That did the Univere controul:
With awful Reverence his Fate
Did none but his own Orders wait:
As if decreed by Powers Divine,
His Ring hould his own Paport ign;
That Ring that mut avenge the guilt
Of Seas of Blood at Canna (19) pilt.

note.l: —atque ibi magnus
Miranduque Cliens edet ad praetoriaregis,
Donec Bithino libeat vigilare Tyranno.

FINEM ANIMAE laethum Annibali qui omnia inturbabat non gladii, nec bellica intrumenta dabant! nam Italia relicta, in Africam reverus Annibal, Zama in praelio à Scipione devictus, & exilio mulctatus, ad Antiochum Syriae Regem profugit, quem potquam de pace cum Romanis upectum deeruit, & ad Pruiam Bythiniae regem e contulit, pro quo adverus Eumenem victor bellum gerit; quo cognito; Romani mittunt ad Pruiam, Quintum Flaminium Legatum uum, ut ibi Annibal daretur ad Romam perducendus, quo Annibali olfacto, hauto veneno, quod emper ub annuli gemma habuerat Romanam malitiam illuit. Finem animae quae res humanas micuit olim,
Non glad • i, non axa dabunt, nec tela: ed ille
Cannarum vindex, & tanti anguinis ultor

ANNULUS: ub cujus palea in hunc uum Annibal venenum in omni tempore paratum habuit, annulus Cannarum vindex, & ultor modii annulorum, quos Senatorum & Equitum Gannis caeorum digitis detractos Carthaginem miit. Annulus.

div.l: No other means was found for Rome
To be ecure from fears to come,
But poor abandon'd Annibal
A weak old Sacrifice mut fall.
Go Mad-man, act thy frantick part,
Climb horrid Alps, with pains and art,
To be with mighty reputation
The ubject of a Declamation.
One World's too mean a trifling thing
For the Young (20) Macedonian King,
He raves like one in Banihment
In narrow craggy Iland pent:
In one poor Globe does weat and queeze,

note.l: Wedg'd in and crampt in Little-Eae.

—I DEMENS: Poeta Sarcamicus inultat jam Annibali, qui jam mortu •• ex tot laboribus, tot tumultibus, bellis, cladibus, nihil reliqui habeat, quam ut cholaticis pueris in cholis, materiam declamandi praebeat. i demens, & avas curre per Alpes
t pueris placeas, & declamatio fias.

UNUS PELLEO JUVENI: Aexandro magno in Pella Macedoniae urbe nato, qui cum adhuc juvenis Anaxarchum Philoophum de infinitis mundis audiet differentem, flevie dicitur, & dixie me mierum qui unius mundi Dominus nondum factus um. nus Pellaeo Juveni non ufficit orbis:
AESTUAT: Quai in anguto conclavi clauus, in quo vix piritum poit ducere. Aetuat infelix anguto limite mundi
t GyaraeCLAUSUS: Gyara vel Seripho angutiimis Inulis ad quas maxime teriles • acineroi mittebantur, graviimi exilii locus. clauus copulis, parvaque Seripho.

div.l: But he who humane race once corn'd,
Gave out high Jove (21) King Phillip horn'd,
While manag'd Oracles declare
The Spark, great Ammons Son and Heir;
At Babylon (22) for all his huffing,
Finds ample room in narrow Coffin.
Man wells with bombat of inventions:
When trip'd Death hews his true dimenions.
We will believe wild Xerxes rent
Mount Athos (23) from the Continent,
And in a frolick made a hift
To et it in the ea a drift:
What e're Romancing Greek dares tell,
Greece, that for Cracking bears the Bell:

note.l: Cum tamen a figulis munit am intraveritURBEM: Babylonem quam Semiramis cocto à figulis latere muris cinxit & circumdedit. urbem,

div.l: With hips pav'd o're the Hellepont,
And built a floating bridge upon't:
Drove Chariots o're by this device,
As lately Coaches on the Ice.
He led o numberles a Rout,
As at one Meal drank Rivers out.
The Kings-Health carce could go about:
With many like amazing Feats
Sostratus Giddy Mue repeats,
With damp wing in her drunken heats.
This Tyrant we in torys find
was us'd to whip and Flogge the winde,
Their Jayler Aeolus (24) in Prion,
Ne're firk'd them with o little reaon:

In Corum, atque Eurum olitus aevire flageliis
Barbarus, Aeolio nunquam hoc in carcere paos,

div.l: Nor could blew Neptunes (25) Godhead ave him,
But he with Fetters mut enlave him.
'Twas well he cap'd his fury o,
And was not whip'd and branded too.
He mut be a Complaiant God,
Will budg at uch a Bedlam's nodd.
But after all thee Roaring freaks,
Routed and broak he homewards neaks;
Abandons all to'th Conqu'ring Greeks,
And Ferry's (26) o're in Fiher-boat,
Through Shoals of Carcaes afloat;
His hopes all Vaniht, bilk'd of all
His gaudy dreams, ee Prides jut fall.
The frequent Subject of our prayers,
Is length of life, and many years.

div.l: We boldly urge thee fair Petitions
In health & icknes; all conditions:
But what inceant plagues and ills
The Gulf of Age with michief fills?
Where meeting tides of orrows flow
As Rivers in the Ocean do.
Ugly deform'd the frightful Elves
Deteted grow, unlike themelves.
Intead of skin, on their out-ide
A wither'd and dicolour'd hide;
They with long Nayles, like tallons claw
Their rivell'd toothles lanthorn jaw:
As a lean mumping Grandam Ape
Her hollow wrinkled chops doth crape,

div.l: Bright glorious Youth inchants our ight
With various objects of delight;
This a more handome face can how
Than that call graceful well-hap'd Beau:
In ong and dance this park is rare,
He Fences, Rides, Vaults, flings the Bar.
No diffr'ing forms our fancy trike,
In extream age, they're all alike;
Weak trembling voice, their hair all hed
Off from their paralitick head.
Th'old Dotard to new Childhood comes,
A dripping Noe, and toothles Gums:
While his loath'd painful Dreggs of Life
Naueat his Children and his Wife;

div.l: So loath'd, makes ev'n the Stomack rie
Of Rogues, who fawn for Legacies.
Their Pallat's gon, nor Wine, nor Meat,
Can pleae their no Tat when they eat.
Nor Beauty moves, nor Cupids dart:
Forgetfulnes has eiz'd that part.
Long ince he there has been bewitcht,
'Tis a longe Age ince lat he itcht.
Obequious hand cannot excite
The bafled Craven to the fight;
From hoary loynes, and aples trunk,
In vain trives the indutrious punk
To raie the nerve quite num'd and hrunk.

div.l: In Limberhams, if Will urvive,
The impotents new ways contrive:
Having exhauted Natures Source
To filthy arts will have recoure.
His Hearing next is lot, what joys
Can he receive from Mintril Boys:
Once in their Golden Liv'rys, lac'd,
Before retrenchment had uncas'd:
What boots a Leon on the flute,
Or ifA Peron famous for his Skill and Hand on the Lute. La' Tou'r hould touch his Lute.
If he would pas his time at th' Opera,
'Tis all to him an idle Foppery;
Since plac'd either remote or near,
No Actors voice can reach his ear.

div.l: He carcely hears the neighbr'ng noye,
Of Cornets, Trumpets, or Ho-boyes.
His ervant in his ear mut hollow
Who viits, or what hour does follow.
Through his chill veins, no pule does beat
Lifes march; them only Feavers heat;
All Maladies unite their force,
Beieging round his rotten coure.
And hould I trive of each dieae,
To give the names and qualities.
I'de ooner muter all the kept
Stallions have cat Aurelia lept:
Reckon thoe Quacks lat Autum kild;
And graves byThe new-found-wells at Ilington o called. Louy-Tunbridge fill'd.

Quem dicat venie puer, quot nunciat horas.

div.l: What fellow Subjects were for Gold,
As Slaves, by needy Vice-Roy old.
Each heir by dice, drink, whores, or masking
Or Stitead brought unto theThe Cant word for a Prion. Naskin;
Or Gallants Back in am'rous play,
Mall Hinton dreyn'd dry in a day:
Count every School boy, name each Child
By Chickin-treading Pedant poyl'd.
Survey each Lordly Seat and Mannour
Poet by valet Pimp of Honour.
For Pains in back and knees this cryes;
This mourns the los of both his eyes;
Envyes the pur-blind; with pale lips,
From others fingers feeds and ipps:

div.l: With mouth wide ope like barrel bung,
Or gapeing bill of wallows young;
To whom the hungry Old-one brings
The hunted prey with Joyful wings.
But the num'd brains tupidity,
Does all the members los out-vy:
When th' Organs of the mind hall leave,
To do their Office, and bereave
Of Memory, then they forego,
The knowledge both of friend and foe;
Forget their Ancient Servants quite,
And friends with whom they upp'd lat night;
Their Children they no longer know;
And by unnat'ral Will betow
