Quos genuit, quos eduxit; namNAM CODICE SAEVO; Saevis, iniquis, et injutis, Tetamenti tabulis, uos liberos exhaeredant. codice aevo

div.l: Their goods, on their lewd Cockatrice,
Whoe Mouth's the very ink of Vice:
So much it's artifice prevails,
Above all Charms of wanton Tailes.
Who many years at Whettone ply'd,
Morefields and other Stews beide;
At Brothel doors tood wheedling in
Unwary Woodcocks to the Gin;
If the Minds faculties continue
Firm, and in age till vigorous in you,
What troubles mut afflict your thoughts,
While your lov'd children crowd Church-vaults
Uh'red by you, Wives, Brothers, come
To Natures dark retiring room.

note.l:
Haredes vetat ee uos,BONA: tota ferunturad Phialem meritricem & • ellatricem uam, quam ex ae haeredem coatituit, quae eni libidinoo & irrumatori fellandi obequio ervi •
bat, ejuque animum ibi devinciebat. bona tot a feruntur
Ad Phial • m: ta • tum artificis valet halitus oris,

l.note: QUOD: per os intelligit Phialem meritricem: quae teterat id et more meriticio praetabat Lupanari, nam meritrices prae otium protibuli vel fornicis blanditiis cortatores allicientes, contitere olebant.
l.hi: Quod tet • rat multis in Carcere fornicis annis.

l.note: UT VIGEANT: tamen multi • tiam in extrema enectute, corpo • e, & animo vigeant. Repondit Poeta objectioni; Ut maxime vigeant, tamen in longa illa vita, multa quae nolint, vident, omni morte graviora. Ut mortem filiorum, conjugis, fratris, ororis, & allos luctus, maerores, & aerumnas innumeras.
l.hi: t vigeant enus animi, ducenda tamen unt

note.l: Fumra natorum, rogus apiciendus amatae
Conjugis, & fratris.—

div.l: Nor can your care or orrow ave
Your belov'd Siters from the Grave.
Thee are the Comforts always wait
On thoe who long defer their Fate.
Still the freh laughter of their Houe
Malitiouly their grief renews:
While cruel providence decreed
They mut grow old in mourning weed.
Death Nature's debt, where long delay'd
With cruel Uury is paid.
King (27) Netor, Homers Records how
In length of life, came next the Crow,
Wore out more lives, as tory's told,
Than Cat, Intayl, or Copy-hold.
His happy years were jutly wondred,
That had urviv'd above three hundred.

note.l: —plenaeque ororibusURNAE: vaa in quibus mortuorum cineres componebantur, potquam corpus arient. urnae
Haec data poena diu viventibus, ut renovata
Semper clade domus multis in luctibus, inque
Perpetuo maerore & nigra vete enecunt.

l.note: REX PILIUS: Netor, cujus exemplo demontrat, illos qui di • vivunt multa mala experire. Dicitur tertiam uque aetatem vixie id et 300 anno, & proxime ad cornicis aetatem acceit, quae vivere dicitur novem aecula vel aetates.
l.hi: Rex Pylius, magno i quicquam credis Homero,

note.l: Exemplum vitae • uit a cornice ecundae.

div.l: Bore Winters Frots, and Summers thirt,
As oft drank wine upon the mut.
See in what melancholly trains,
Of the three Siters he complains;
Why they hould pin his Thread o tough
Of cured everlating tuff:
Harh Laws! when the urviving Sire
Waits bearded Son to fun'ral fire.
In rage expotulates why he
Survives to o much miery:
And o what Sin of his, the Hate
Of Heavens Decrees uch lingring Fate:
So Peleus for Achilles (28) cry'd,
Snatch'd in the Temple from his Bride,
Death in the nick the Banes deny'd:

note.l: Felix nimirum, qui tot per ecula mortem
Ditulit, aique uos jamDEXTRA: Graeci numerum infra centum digitis initrae numerabantur, numerum verò centarium & illo majorem digitis dextrae. dextra comput at annos,
Quique novum toties mutum bibit, oro, parumper
Attendas, quantum de legibus ipe queratur

l.note: FACTORUM Parcarum: quod Atropos non citius tamen abruperit.
l.hi: Factorum, & nimio de tamine, cum videt
l.note: ACRIS: fortis, bellicoi. Hic enim Antilochus cum patri opem ferre vellet a Memnone • uit occius.
ANTILOCHI: cum deflet filium uum cum ejus cadaver combureretur.
l.hi: Antilochi barbam ardentem: tum quaerit ab omni

note.l: Quiquis adet ocius: cur haec in tempore duret,
Quid facinus dignum tam longo admierit aev • .
Haec eademPELEUS: Aeaci filius, Pater Achillis, qui cum Pollixinae nuptias peraret in Templo Apolinis, ab Paride & Diaphob • agittis con • o •• us et. Peleus raptum cum luget A • hillem.

div.l: Ulyes aged Sire did moan
The ten years ramble of his Son:
Priam (29) had dy'd a happy hade
E're Troy had been in rubbih lay'd
His mournful Rites with Pomp and State,
Perform'd by peaceful Magitrate;
His Corps born up by Hectors houlder,
(Than whom, no Mortal e're was bolder)
And's fifty Sons, tall Bully-Rocks,
As ever prung from Kingly Stocks.
E're Fair Caandra Fate fore knowing
Bewayl'd ack'd Troy, with eyes o're-flowing;
Had he been dead as any Herring,
E're Paris went a privateering;

note.l: AtqueALIUS: Laertes enex lugens filium uum Ulyem Ithacae ducem, orbem decem annos pererrantem & navigantem. alius, cui fas Ithacum l • gere natantem.

l.note: INCOLUMI TROJA: id et felix etiam fuiet Priamus, i Troja adhuc incolumi, & florente regno, vel ante excidium, & Trojae incendium, mort • us uiet, tunc enim magnis olemnibus à quinquaginta fili • s uis funus ejus deductum fuiet, & tot mala, regnique • ui interitum, non uiet expertus.
l.hi: Incolumi Tro • a Primus veniet • ad umbras

note.l: Aaraei magnis olennibus, H • ctore funus
Portante, ac reliquis fractrumCERVICIBUS. Ex veterum conuetudine hoc dicit, nam filii olim funus patris portabat. cervicibus, inter
Iliadum lacrymas, ut primos eder • planctus

l.note: CASSANDRA: Quia vates erat, & futuri concia mortem Patris civiet, & ante reliquas orores uas calamitates Patris & Trojae fleviet.

note.l: Si foret extinctus divero tempore, quo non

Creperat audacesPARIS: Si mortuus • uiet Priamus, priuquam Paris • ilius, ejus audaces naves illas aedificabat, quibus H • llenam Menelai Conjugem abducebat, quae rapina caua uit excidii urbis Trojani. Paris aediicare Carinas.

div.l: For Whores and Plunder play'd le • d Tricks,
Which to the Gutts provok'd the Greeks.
Who Clubbing in Revenge o' re-turn'd
Their State, and Pyrat-City burn'd:
At lat the trembling King throw's by
His Turbant, and to's arms does fly;
Buckles on's harnes, and invirons
His weak limbs with unweildy irons.
And at Joves Shrine reignes his life,
As an old Ox under the Knife.
His weak-worn ueles neck does bow,
Caheir'd from the ungrateful Plow.
His griefs how er'e a period found,
And in deaths deep abys were drown'd.

note.l: Long a dies igitur quid contulit? omnia vidif
Evera, & flammis Aiam ferroque cadentem.
Tunc miles tremulus poita tulit arma Tiara,
Et ruit ante aram ummi Jovis, ut vetulus Bos,
Qui domini cultris tenue & mierabile collum
Praebet, ab ingrato jam fatiditus aratro.
EXITUS: demontrat Poeta his verbis, mortem & fatum Priami fuie tolerabilem & multo optabiliorem, quam mierimae relictae conjugis ejus Hecubae. Exitus ille utrunque hominis.

div.l: The Gods to his grim narling wife,
Prolong'd indignities with life.
Chang'd and deform'd to uch a pitch,
Through rage, he dy'd, a barking bitch.
Why hould we for Examples roam
Abroad, when choice are found at home?
The (30) Pontick King I will omit,
And Craeus taught by Solons wit.
We can pronounce none happy, none,
Till the lat Sand of life be run.
None jutly we good Actors call,
In lifes farce, till deaths Curtains fall.
(31) Marius long-life was th'only reaon,
Of Exile and Minturnian Prion.

note.l: —Sed torva canino

LATRAVIT: Hecuba capta Troja in canem vera fuit ut Ovidius libro 13 Metamorphos & Virgilius: occaio fabulae putatur, quod cum a Graecis captiva abduceretur & iliui Polidori corpus in mare fluctuantem agnoviet, quoniam aliter injuriam ulcici non poet, amia patentia, Graecos inanibus laceiverit convitiis. Latravit rictu, quae pot hunc vixerat, uxor.

Fetino ad notros, &REGEM: Mithridatem qui vixit anno 69 & cum Romanis 40 annos varia bella geit 57 annis regnavit: a Sylla, Lucullo, & Pompeio ter victus fuit, vitae & belli taedia; cum non poet veneno gladio vitam finivit. regem traneo Ponti,

ET CRAESUM: Regem Lydiae ditiimum Solonem ofteno theauro rogavit vidiet ne aliquem feliciorem? repondit Philoophus neminem b • atum judicandum ante obitum, ic Ovidius, Ante obitum nemo upremaque funera felix. Et Craeum, quem vox juti facunda Solonis
Repicere ad longae juit patia ultima vitae.
EXILIUM: Marium Arpinarem epties Conul. vide Annotatione. Exilium & carcer, Minturnarumque paludes,

div.l: Made him beg bread for his relief,
In Carthage where he once was chief.
Nature did ne'r produce of old,
Or Rome a happier man behold.
Then Marius was, when he victorious,
Proceion made in Chariot glorious;
With Trophys and attending poyles,
And Captives chain'd in ranks and files.
Had Death natch'd his Tryumphing Spirit,
That day, none e're had match'd his merit.
Kind Fate, deigning to befriend
Great (32) Pompey, did a Feaver end,
That hould with favourable doom,
Prevent his mieries to come.

note.l: Et mendicatus victa Carthagine panis,
Hinc cauas habuere. Quid illo cive tuli • t
Natura in terris, quid Roma beatius unquam,
Si circum ducto Captivorum agmine, & omni,
Bellorum pompa, animam exhalaet opimam,
Cum de I • utoni • o vellet decendere curru?

ProvidaPOMPEIO: Exemplum Pompeii magni, qui ante bellum civile Correptus et ebre • aventi & benevola, quia mortem & ignominiam provide prevenire praecaveret, quae mors cum honor • ante bellum civile illi optanda fuiet ne victus, ab Achilla obtruncaretur. Pompeio dederat Campania felres
Optandas:—

div.l: Whole Nations for his danger griev'd;
Their publick prayers obtain, Repriev'd.
Fate then that honour'd head did ave,
Which he t' inulting Caear gave.
Slow Lentulus ne're underwent,
For Treaon uch a Punihment:
Nor Rah Cethegus, (33) Cataline
A Corps intire in Arms did Shine.
'Tis the fond Mothers contant prayer
Her Children may be paing Fair.
Excelling far all other faces,
In beauty and rare Charming graces.
Which Boon they beg with ighs and groans,
Inceantly on Marrow-bones.

note.l: —Sed multae rbes, &PUBLICA VOTA quae a multis urbibus pro alute Pompeii Diis offerebantur & quae illum tantum a morte eripuerunt ut potea mieriùs moreretur ab Achilla occius. publica vota
Vicerunt, igitur Fortuna ipius, & urbis
SERVATUM Caput: Per preces aliquandiu ervatum, donec potea Pompeii a Caeare victi Caput amputatione e •• et ablatum. Servatum victo caput abtulit. Hoc Cruciatu
Lentulus, hac paenae caruit, ceciditque Cethegus
INTEGER: c. ine capitis amputatione quod coptice dicit. Integer, & jacuit Catilina cadavere toto.
FORMAM: Tranit poeta à divitiis Honoribus, &c. ad votum pulchritudinis aeque cum caerteris pernitioum. Formam optat Modico pueris, Majore puellis
Murmure, cum Veneris fanum videt anxia mater

div.l: Who jutly blames a Mothers joy,
That huggs her wanton well-hung-boy.
Or if for joy Latona cry,
To ee her pretty daughter Dy:
Yet bright (34) Lucretias ullen fate,
Shews fair-ones are not fortunate.
(35) Virginia's chance may well confute you;
Good luck don't always wait on beauty:
Th' unhappy Fair's in wore etate,
Than a crump rich and fortunate.
Concern for handome boys does make,
Ill-boading Parents hearts to ake.
Still dreading michiefs when they ee,
Few fair ones fam'd for Chatity.

note.l: —cur tamen, inquit
Corripias? pulchra gaudet Latona Diana.
Sed vetat optari faciem Lucretia, qualem

Ipa habuit, cuperetRUTILAE: Lura Rutila, gibboa & deformis. 97 annos exceit. RutilaeVIRGINIA: a Patre uo interempta, ne ab Appio Decemviro ervitutem redigeretur, & catitate violaretur. Virginia gibbum
Accip • re, atque uum Rutilae dare. Filius autem
Corporis egregii mieros trepidoque parentes
Semper habet—

div.l: Beauty and Virtue often jarr,
Joyn'd in one Peron eldom are;
Though bred in honet Country Cell,
Where no debauch'd Examples dwell;
Whence Lut is banih't, Vertue ways,
As in Queen Dick's plain honet days.
Though Nature's bounteous hand hould plant
All Graces that can make a Saint;
And in one modet Cheek unite
The bluhing Red Roe with the White;
What ever Nature can impart,
Nature more prevalent than Art;
Yet Vice will try her utmot Power,
And Court them in a golden Shower:

note.l: —Rara est adeo Concordia formae
Atque pudicitiae; anctos licetHORRIDA: implex & incluta domus a libidine aliena. horrida mores
Tradiderit domus, ac veteres imitataSABINAS: mulieres catiimas. Sabinas,
Praeterea catum ingenium, vult umque modeto
Sanguine ferventem tribuat natura benigna
Larga manu (quid enim puero conferre potet plus
Cutode & curaNATURA: naturae vis ad pudicitiam inclinata multò prevalentior intitutione, doctrina & educatione. natura potentior omni?)

div.l: To kidd-nap Youth will lye in wait,
And nap it er'e at Mans Etate.
So to corrupting bribes they'le trut,
They'le Parents tempt for bawds to lut:
No Tyrant will the ill-hap'd chue
For Guardian Eunuchs for their Stews.
Or on a Youth deform'd will pitch,
To cure his Sodomitick itch.
Go now applaud thy fair Sons Fate,
For whom perhaps wore dangers wait.
Let him turn Stallion to the Town,
And dread each hair-brain'd Husband's frown.
And undergo for punihment,
What inrag'd Cuckolds can invent.

note.l: NON LICET, &c. Scilicet i pulchri unt aut catrantur aut corrumpuntur (i. e.) aut padones fiunt vel cinaedi. Non licet ee viros: nam prodiga corruptoris
Improbitas ipos audet tentare parentes.
Tanta in muneribus fiducia. Nullus ephebum
Deformem aeva catravit inARCE: In Arce Tarpeia olebat Nero catrare pueros. arce Tyrannus.
NecPRAETEXTATUM: nobilem puerum ad tuprum rapuit. praetextatum rapuit Nero Loripedem, nec
Strumoum, atque utero pariter, gibboque tumentem.
I nunc, & juvenis pecie laetare tui, quem
Major a expectant dicrimina. Fiet adulter
Publicus, & poenas metuet, quacunque mariti
Irati debent.—

div.l: Ne're let him think by Wit or Care
Still luckily to cape the nare:
Surpriz'd, undone, Trappan'd, beet,
He'le fall like Mars into the Net.
Then hall revenge quit his old Scores,
And pay him home for pat Amours:
They'le lit his Noe, or Crop his Ears,
And whip off Gun and Bandileers:
Dipatch with Poyon, Steel, or Bullet,
Or Fundament plugg'd with a (36) Mullet.
But thy Endimion hall inflame
None but ome choice fair wealthy Dame,
By whom, profuely cram'd with coin,
His peerles Pomp hall all out-hine.

note.l: —nec erit felicior astro
MARTIS: depreni in laqueis cum Venere in adulterio. Martis ut in laqueos nunquam incidat. Exigit autem
Interdum ille dolor plus, quam lex ulla dolori
Conceit. Necat hic ferro, ecat ille cruentis

Verberibus, quodam moechos &MUGILIS: Vetus deprenorum maechorum upplicium, cum depil •
bant nates cinere calido, & tunc mugiles, pices quodam cum grandi capite in podicem immittebant. mugilis intrat.
Sed tuusNATUS: tuus formous ut Endimion à luna amatus. Endimion dilectae fiet adulter
Matronoe:—

div.l: But when through vain Expence, or Play,
His hoarded Bank hall melt away;
He for recruit, mut let to hire
His Hackney Back, to the deire
Of ome old filthy Hagg for coyn,
And ell the labour of his Chine;
Then he mut trip and buckle to't,
Or from loath'd Task mut reap no fruit.
Whither by Nature free or bae;
No Buttock's hide-bound in this cae:
Or will be nigardly and grudge
A lib'ral al'ry to her drudge.
And if he 'cape thee threatning Rocks,
He'le urely hipwrack on the Pox:

note.l: —mox cum dederitSERVILIA: turpis & de • ormis, mater Bruti. Servilia nummos

Fiet & illius quam non amat,EXUET: omnia dabit, ve • ip
• a ornamenta corporis, etiam ve
• timenta ua ad atisficiendam libidinem. exuet omnem
Corporis ornatum; quid enim ulla negaveritUDIS: per udum inguen, membrum muliebre intelligitur. udis
Inguinibus, • ive et haecHIPPIA: ive it prodiga & nobilis ut Hippia, vel avara, ut Catulla. Hippia ive Catulla?
DETERIOR: (i. e.) vel peima faemina habet omnes mores, viz: liberalitatem beneficentiam &c. in remunerandis Amatoribus. D • terior totos habet illic faemina mores.

div.l: Ere throughly ripe he'l rot away,
Like early fruits that oon decay:
His mall remaining tock he trucks,
With Quack for dyet-drink and Flux;
In which his Noe and Pallat fall,
Rots peice-meal, noyome grown to all;
Ends his loath'd life in Hopitall.
What harm will honet Beauty do,
He may prove Chat, and handome too.
What did hisHippolito. rigid Vertue boot,
That baulk'd his Step-dames lutful uite:
What did (37) Bellerephon betyde,
When he returns of love deny'd?
In both their Queans Revenge did Reign,
Rows'd by repule of Cold Didain.

note.l: Sed cat • quid forma nocet?QUID &c: repondit hic objectioni, otendens exempla catitatis atalis & exitialis in Hippolito & Bellerophonte. Hippolitus erat filius Theei, à Novercà Phaedriâ cujus inceto amori non repondebat, apud patrem tupri falo accuatus, dum patris iram ugeret, ab equis territis disjectus curru & dicerptus et. Bellerophon infinitis periculis expoitus et, propter contemptum amorem Sthenobeae Praeti Regis Uxoris. quid profuit immo
Hipp • lyto grave propoitum, quid Bellerophonti?
Erubuit nen pe haec, ceu fatidita repulo.
Nec Sthenobae • minus quamCRESSA: Phaedria ic dicta, quia Minoidis Cretenium Regis Pilia, Crea excanduit, & e
Conc • ere ambae—

div.l: Then Women rage with cruel't pite
When hame their hatred does excite:
When trifling Lovers eaons loe,
And kind advances do refue:
From loath'd Contempt of profer'd love
Their Breats with furious tranports move.
Call Council quickly to advie,
Our preent Cae proves very nice:
Here's Caears (38) Wife reolv'd to marry,
Nor for the Emperours Death will tarry.
She has deign'd with lutful Eyes
The Noble Youth her Sacrifice.
The Priet and honour'd Guets invites
To witnes Matrimonial Rites.

note.l: —mul • er aeviima tunc est,
Cum timulos odio pudor admovet. Elige quid nam
Suadendum ee putes, cui nubere Caearis uxor

Detinat.OPTIMUS: Caius Silius, praenobilis Romanus, in quem exarit Mealina Uxor Claudii (faemina Libidinis montrum) & qui coactus dimia uxore ua palam Mealinam ducere, re cognita ab Imperatore necatus erat. optimus hic, & formoiimus idem
Gentis Patriciae rapitur mier extinguendus
Mealinae occulis: dudum edet illa parato
FLAMEOLO: quo nova nupta operitur. Flameolo—

div.l: The Portion's told, the Genial Bed
With Pomp is in the Garden pread:
Does with Capricious fancy burn;
Marriage can only erve her turn:
With which, if he will not comply
He tempts his preent detiny:
What hall he do? obedience give,
And that may gain a hort reprieve:
Till all the Town the Story hears;
At lat 'twill reach the Prince's ears.
There's hopes in that, for the digrace
The Cuckold learns in the lat place:
Then to her Will obedience pay;
Your Fate may thence admit delay,

note.l: —Tyriuque palam genialis in hortis
Sternitur, & rituDECIES CENTENA: Setertia, qui numerus erat legitimus & olemnis in Dote lautiorum, danda marito propter matrimonii onera. decies centena dabuntur
Antiquo, veniet cumSIGNATORIBUS: Qui obignabant tabulas & intrumenta matrimonii. ignatoribusAUSPEX: Nullae nuptiae praeertim Legitimae fiebant ine Aupicio. aupex.
Haec tu ecreta, & paucis commia putabas?
Non nii legitime vult nubere: quid placeat, dic:
Ni parere velis, pereundum erit ante lucernas:
Si celus admittas, dabitur mora parvula, dum res
Nota urbi & populo contin • at Principis aures,
Dedecus ille domus ciet ultimus. interea tu
Obequere imperio—

div.l: If at the rate of uch a Wife
you'l purchae a hort lavih life.
Both ways his certain Fate's decreed
The wretched lovely Youth mut bleed.
Shall men ask nothing then? be wie,
And liten well to ound advice.
Refer deires to Providence,
With thanks take what the Gods dipence.
Let not your tubborn Will repine,
What'ere they hall for you deign.
They better know than human wit,
What does our Exigents befit.
Their wie all-eeing eyes dicern,
And give what bet uits our concern.

note.l: —i tanti vita dierum
Paucorum. Quiquid melius leviuque putaris,
Praebenda et gladio pulchra haec, & candida cervix.
Nil ergo, optabunt homines? Si conilium vis,
Permittes ipis,EXPENDERE: Coniderare. expendere Numinibus, quid
Conveniat nobis, rebuque it utile notris.
Nam pro jucundis aptiima queaque dabunt Dii.

div.l: We blindly harmful things implore
Which they refuing, love us more.
By love and blind deires till led,
Wee're hurryed to the Marriage bed:
With hopes of iue from our Love,
But Heaven foreaw how both would prove;
Forbearing to diturb our Life,
With Bratts unnatural, and dam'd wife.
Pray then, that in a Body ound,
A Firm and Contant mind be found.
A Mind no fear of death can daunt,
Nor Exile, Prion, Paines nor Want.
That jutly reckons death to be
Kind Author of our liberty,
From Fleh, a Goal-Delivery.

note.l: Carior et illis homo, quam ibi. Nos animorum
Impulu, & caeca, magnaque cupidine ducti,
Conjugium petimus, partumque uxoris: at illis
Notum, qui pueri, qualique futura it uxor.
t tamen & pocas aliquid, voveaque acellis
EXTA: Intetina delicata. Exta, & candiduli divinaTOMACULA: Farcimina pinguia è Porcinis carnibus. tomacula porci:
Orandum et, ut it mens ana in corpore ano.
Fortem poce animum, mortis terrore carentem,
Qui patium <> extremum inter munera ponat
Naturae—

div.l: Banihing Paion from our Bret,
Reting Content with what's poet.
That ev'ry honet Action loves,
And Great Alcides (39) toyles approves,
Above the Luts, Feats, beds of Down,
Which did Sardanapalus (40) drown.
This, mortals to themelves may give;
Vertue's, the happy rule to live.
Chance bears no way, where Widome Rules,
An empty Name, ador'd by fools.
Folly Blinde Fortune did Create
A Goddes, and to Heaven Tranlate.

note.l: —qui ferre queat quocunque labores,
Neciat iraci, cupiat nil, &POTIORES: praeferendos. potiores
Herculis aerumnas, credat, aevoque labores,
Et Venere, & caenis, & plumaSARDANAPALI: Ultimus Ayriorum Rex, omni libidini effoeminatae deditus. Sardanapali.
Montro, quod ipe tibi pois dare, Semita certe
Tranquillae per virtutem patet unica vitae.
NullumNUMEN HABES: Scilicet tu Fortuna nullum numen habes. i. e. non Dea exitimaris a prudenti homine. Numen habes i it prudentia:NOS: ed nos tolidi homines facimus Fortunam Deam notram. nos, te
Nos facimus, Fortuna, Deam, coeloqu • locamus.

div.head: THE ANNOTATIONS ON THE Tenth SATYR.
div.p: (1.) IN this Wie Satyr, the Author does reprove and accue the Ignorance of Mankind, imploring things of the Gods, which often prove prejudicial; As, Riches, Honours, Martial-Glory, Long-Life, & Beauty: But neglect to ask Endowments and Bleings of the Mind; as, Widom, Vertue, Jutice, and Integrity of Life, which alone can be eteemed Real Good, of which neither Chance, Violence, nor Shipwrack can deprive us; true and olid Happines coniting in the Indolency of the Body, and tranquility of the Mind; and hews that very few men in the World, viz. from Cadiz an Iland in Spain, at the Mouth of the Streights of Gibralter, which in our Authors time, was thought the Bounds of the Wetern World, and where Hercules placed his Pillars, to the Famous River Ganges, Eatward, whoe Head arieing in Mount Caucaus in Scythia, runs a long Coure through the Eastern-Indies, whoe Channel where narrowet, is 8 miles broad, and about 20 where widet; and in the hallowet place 100 Foot deep. Page 1st.

(2) Milo: The Poet oberving, that many Eminent in Civil and Military Affairs, & fam'd for Eloquence, truting to their own Abilities have been ruin'd; gives a lively Intance of one betray'd by his own trength; in Milo the Crotan, who unfortunately preuming on his Gygantick trength, in an Attempt to rive an Oak, had his Arm wedged in the Trunk; whence not having power to diengage himelf, he was held in a Trapp in the olitary Woods, where he became a Prey to Wild Beats. This Milo in the Olympick Games carryed an Ox on his back a furlong, and after lew him at one Blow of his Fit, and the ame day intirely eat him up. Page 4th.

(3) In Neroes: The Poet oberves this Emperour infamous for Tyranny, Injutice, and all manner of Villany & Wickednes; who took all unjut advantages to trappan and take away the Lives of his wealthiet Subjects, thereby to poes himelf of their Etates, and proceeded to uch a height, he did not pare the Lives of his Dometick Servants and Favourites, imbrewing his hands in the
Blood of his Mother, Brother, and Wife; and others of his nearet Relations. Page 5th.

(4) Longinus: Caius Caius Longinus the Lawyer, whom Nero commanded to be lain, being charged with no other Crime, but having the Statue of Caeius (one of Caar's Murderers) in his houe. But his great Riches and Poeions was the true reaon of his Death. Page 6th.

(5) Seneca: The Tutor of Nero, who by the favour of the Emperour, in his ten years ole Minitry of Affairs, had amaed together a vat Treaure, and got plendid Gardens and Poeions; but lot them all by the Command of his cruel Pupil, with his life. As alo did the rich Family of the Laterani. Page 6th.

(6) The brace of Wie-men: Are meant Democritus of Abdera the laughing, and Heraclitus of Epheus, the weeping Philoopher; the firt, in a careles merry humour, continually coffing and deriding the Vanity and Foppery of Mankind; the other bewailing their Folly and Misfortune. Page 8th.

(7) Knees: It was cutomary with the Antients, when they had any great or coniderable Requet or Boon to beg of the Gods, to write their Requet in Paper or waxen Tables; together, with a Conditional Vow, which they promied to perform if they obtained their uit; which being ealed, they left fatned to the Knees of the God, from whom the Bleing was expected; in which if they proved uccesful, they took off the Paper o fatened, and performed their Vow. Page 12th

(8) Clius Sejanus: A Tucan born, he was in o great favour with the Emperour Tyberius, that he denyed him nothing: He was made Colleague in the Conulhip and Roman Empire with Tyberius, was likewie Prefect of the Pretorian Bands, and grand Mater of the Pallace: Publick Statues were erected to him, and the Romans ued to wear by his Fortune; his Birth-day was kept a Fetival: Yet falling into Digrace with Tyberius, by whom, he with others, were upected to have conpired his Death; the Emperour from the Iland of Capra ent a long Epitle to the Senate, charging Sejanus with Ingratitude againt the life of Caear; whereupon he was by the Senate forthwith Condemned with his whole Family; and the ame day having his hands bound behind him, was by the Executioner drawn through the treet to the Scalae Gemoniae; his Statues pulled down with Contempt and Ignominy, his only daughter then but a child was deflour'd and executed by the Hangman. A Notable Example of the mutability of Humane Affairs. Page 13th.
(9) Capra: An Iland near Naples, whither Tyberius retired, pending his time in obcene • ilthy Pleaures, whence he wrote to the Senate againt Sejanus. Page 14th.

(10) Old-Fox: Tyberius who may well merit that Name, being a mot profound diembler, and ubtil Politician, whoe Actions had rendred him o odious to the Romans, that as Suetonius relates on the firt news of his Death, ome of the People cryed out, that he hould be thrown into the Tyber; others would allow no epulchre; others threatned to drag the Body to the Scalae Gemoniae. Page 15th.

(11) Cicero: The Author hews by the Examples of Cicero and Demothenes, that Wit and Eloquence have been pernicious to Orators: Cicero the Chief of the Roman Orators and Philoophers, as appears by his works; he being the firt that tranplanted the Grecian Learning into the Roman Language: He raied himelf through all the degrees of civil Imployments to the Conulhip, being the highet pitch of Honour in the Roman Common-wealth; and in his year of Conulhip, broke and defeated the Conpiracy of Cataline: He made everal invective Orations againt Mark Anthony, which he with evil O men Intituled his Phillippicks, in imitation of Demothenes, who in like manner declaymed againt Phillip of Macedon; but in the turn of the Roman State he was in revenge procribed by Anthony and Augutus, and had his Head and Hands nailed on the Rotrum or Pulpet, whence he declaimed againt Anthony. Page 21t.

(12) Demothenes the Athenian, the mot famous Grecian Orator, and Stout Champion for the Liberty of Greece; he declaimed againt King Phillip, as one who deigned to detroy the Publick Liberty and enlave Greece; for which he was expelled his Country; and again, after Phillips Death recalled: but after Alexanders Death, under the Government of Antipater, dicovering ome Deigns againt his Life, he fled and took Sanctuary in Neptune's Temple, whither Archias the Tragedian came, endeavouring to wheadle him to recoure to Antipater; affirming he had no deign againt him; but their Plott being well undertood by Demothenes, he told Archias, that he had never pleaed him on the Stage as an Actor, and much les now when he played the Part of an Ambaador: but Archias threatning he would draw him out by Force; the Orator told him, he perceived now he was in earnet, whereas before he did but act his Part, and deiring his Patience till he dipatched ome neceary Orders to his Dometicks; he retired to ome ditance, and drew out his Table-Book as if he would write, when ucking Poyon from a quill which he had always kept therein for a dead lift, He expired: thereby mocking the malice and revenge of his Adveraries. Page 21t.

(13) Barbari • n: When Greece Flourihed, She called all the World beides Barbarous: which Title Plautus as freely betows on the Romans; but when Rome came in Power, and Arts Flourihed, he treated the World with the ame language. Page 24th.

(14) Hannibal: Here the Poet paes from Eloquence to Martial-Glory, and inquires what Advantages it brought to that Captain Hannibal, the on of Amilcar, the Carthaginian General, by whom he was in his youth olemnly worn an
Irreconcileable Enemy to the Romans; the Poet traces his life through all the traveres of his properous & advere Fortune, demontrating he had been happier, had he limited his Ambition, and not haraed and conumed Himelf and Country, about uch vain and improbable Deigns of Conquering Italy. Page 25th.

(15) Affrick: He taxes the Haughty and Retles Spirit of Hannibal, who eteemed Affrick, though then one full third part of the known World, too narrow a Stage and obcure a Scene for his Boundles and Ambitious Actions. Page 25th.

(16) Alps: A continued ridge of high Mountains, extending one hundred thouand paces, & dividing France & Germany from Italy: they are continually covered with Snow, from whoe whitenes they took their Denomination in Greek, a < in non-Latin alphabet > trong and afe barricade to the Roman Empire, againt the Gauls and Barbarous Nations. Page 26th.

(17) With Vinegar: Our Author laughs at the ridiculous Relation given by Livy, of Hannibals paing the Alps, reporting, that when the Army was obtructed by a Rock in their paage; they made a vat Pile of Trees, and with the advantage of the Wind, etting them on Fire, they poured Vinegar on the red-hot Stone, which oftned, diolved, and rotted them away; which idle Invention of the Hitorian, is by Polibius omitted as fabulous; for what needs uch an Operation, when before Hannibal's time, the Gauls had five times paed the Alps: It might be neceary the Army making o long a paage, and o tedious, by reaon of the number, and the narrownes, where no Garriages could come up; that each Souldier hould carry his proportion of Bread & Vinegar for the whole Paage; the Vinegar being neceary to make Beveredge with the Mountain Water: Which great Preparation of Vinegar provided for the March, might give occaion to uch Fabulous Report, Page. 26th.

(18) Bythinian Tyrants Gate: Hannibal being overcome by Scipio Affricanus at the Battle of Zama, near Carthage in Affrick; depairing of ucces or afety, fled to Antiochus the King of Syria; but upecting that King was in Treaty to deliver him to the Romans; he left him and went to Pruius King of Bythinia, where, as his General he overcame Eumenes; but the Romans not thinking themelves ecure, while o Politick and Inveterate an Enemy urvived, dealt with Pruius by Embay to deliver him up; which Hanibal dicovering, to prevent hame, dipatched himelf by Poyon, which he always carryed in his Ring for that purpoe: A poor Revenge of Rome, and below the Conideration of o Great and Victorious a Common-wealth. Page 28th.

(19) Canna: Where Hannibal in a pitch't Battle overcame Paulus Emilius, and Terentius Varro, the two Roman Conuls, together with their whole Army, being the Flower of the Roman Militia, killing mot of their Hore, and above
40000 Foot upon the Place; he filled three buhels of Rings, taken from the Fingers of the lain Nobility, which he ent to Carthage as a Witnes of his Victory; and therefore our Poet wittily Remarks, that Hannibals own Ring did revenge the laughter of the Owners of o many Rings at Canna. Page 28th.

(20) Macedonian King: He laughs at the Vanity of Young Alexander, for being melancholly becaue there was but one World could fall to his hare, as not a ufficient Prize for his Ambition: 'tis aid, Alexander hearing a Philoopher endeavouring to prove there were many Worlds, he burt into tears, to his Friends complaining that he had not as yet Conquered One among o many. Page 29th.

(21) Jove: Alexander was o puft up with his Succes againt the Cowardly Effeminate Perians, and tranported to that degree of Pride and Vanity, that he procured and corrupted the Priets of Jupiter Ammon, to receive and own him as the true Son of that God; and et on foot a formal tory, that the God had in a viible Figure convered with his Mother about the time of his Conception; which though it might be politickly done, to awe the upertitious Perians and barbarous Nations, who might think it vain to reit the power of a God, yet it leened him in the Hearts & Opinions of his Gallant & Victorious Macedonians; and by acribing all to ole Valour and Conduct of his Godhip, he robbed every brave Souldier & Commander of his hare of the Honour and Victory. Page 30th.

(22) Babylon: A City of the Perians, built by Semiramis the Wife of Ninus, the Founder of the Ayrian Monarchy; it was urrounded with Walls of brick, being 60 Miles in Compas, 50 Foot in Height, and 200 Foot in Breadth, where Alexander dyed by Poyon: Pythagoras the Magician had foretold, that Babylon hould be fatal to him, where, notwithtanding the Oracle, he was found mortal. Page 30th.

(23) Athos: Here the Poet confirms his Argument with the Example of Xerxes, the Perian King, who not content with his vat Dominions, makes an expedition with a numerous Army into Greece; and as the Greek Hitorians relate, cut a deep trench, wherein he let the Sea, and thereby divided that high Mountain, which was a Promontory from the main Land, and caued Veels to ail round; which is the Expoition the Commentators give of Velificatus Athos; which does not atisfy me, who rather conjecture that Mount Athos abounding with Pines; they were by Xerxes cut down and made into Veels, and then Veleficati or put to ail, and afterwards with them compoed a Bridge over the Hellepont, he adding immediately, contatum claibus eidem—uppoitumque rotis olidum mare. Which if allowed, the ence will be parallel, as if we hould ay; The King in his great Navy put the Forret of D • an to ea, calling the Wood by the name of the Place where it grew: the Poet reflecting on the Greeks, who writing their own Hitory, magnify their own Courage and Conduct, by tuffing their Legends with montrous Fables, expoe their Enemies to deriion, uch as the
making a trench about Athos, and the drinking Rivers dry at one Meal. Page. 30th.

(24) Eolus: the Grecian Hitories tell us, that Xerxes, to hold a Correpondence between Aia and Europe, laid a Bridge of Boats over the Hellepont, at the Place where Setos and Abidos tood, and the Place where now the Dardanelli are placed, where the ea is about a mile broad; where the Current being deep, the Veels could not ride at Anchor againt the tream, but mut be fatened to each other; which long line of Boats upon the firt tiff Gale of Wind, at Eat, then called a Levant, and blowing with the Currant, mut necearily eparate and brake, which was the Fate of Xerxe's Bridge: who to be revenged on Eurus or the Eat Wind, caued everal Thouands of his Army being drawn up upon the hoar, with rods to trike and whip againt the Winde; the Poet reflecting on the folly of the interprize, ays in a jeer, Eolus the Prince of the Winds, under whoe Government and retraint they are kept in the Caverns of the Earth, never ued his Subjects the Winds o Barbarouly. Page 31.

(25) Neptune: An Ironical Relation of a freak of Xerxe's, who being offended with Neptune, as well as the VVinds, for breaking his Bridge; did cat Fetters and Manacles into the Sea, to hew he had dominion over Neptune, & could chain him at his pleaure as well as courge the VVinds: & perhaps to as much purpoe as the Duke of Venice with olemn Pompe and State does yearly epoue the Adriatick by throwing a Ring with Ceremony into that Sea; the Poet oberves, that Neptune was kindly dealt with, that he was not branded as fugitive laves ued to be erved. Page 32.

(26) Ferrys: Xerxe's being overcome by the Greeks neer Salamine, under the Conduct of Themitocles with great laughter, and a Total defeat of his Navy, fled with a few by Land to Abidos; and finding the Bridge broken, was in a great Terrour wafted over in a mall fiherboat, concluding o great and glorious an expedition with a bae and hameful flight. Page 32.

(27) Netor King of Pylos: The VViet and mot Eloquent of all the Greeks, who continued trong and vigorous at an extream age, being near 300 years old when he went to the Seige of Troy: by his rare Example, the Poet hews the unavoidable grief and calamities, that necearily attend old age, when at the death of his Son he introduced him in a bitter complaint againt the detinies, for prolonging his mierable life. Page 41.

(28) Peleus the Son of Eacus, and Father of Achilles the valiant Greek, who could not be comforted for the death of his valiant Son lain in the Temple of Apollo by Paris and Diaphobus, in the intant when he attended to Marry Pollixena their Siter. Page 42.

(29) Priam: the lat King of Troy, who urviving to a great age, lived to ee
his chief City taken, acked and burnt with the laughter of his numerous iue, and ubjects, having Fifty Sons, and was himelf lain in the Temple of Jupiter. The Poet oberves he had been happy, had he dyed before thee Calamities, which was-all he gained by his Long-Life; yet puruing his Argument againt Long-Life, he prefers his Fate, though it met a ditatrous Concluion before his Wife Hecuba's who urviveing him, was transformed into a Bitch. Page 43d.

(30) The Pontick King: Mithridates, who lived 69 years, and reigned 57, and waged continual war with the Romans 40 years; by whom he was thrice overcome under the Conduct of Scylla, Lucullus, and Pompey; his affairs were at lat reduced to that extreamity, that he attempted to detroy himelf by Poyon, but finding by Antidotes, he had o fortified his Body, it would not work the deired Effect: he perfected his Intention with a Doe of cold Iron. Page 45th.

(31) Caius Macius: Produced as another Intance of the misfortune of Long-Life; he led the beginning of his Life as a labouring Husband-man, and after erved as a common Souldier, and paing through everal degrees of the Army, at length obtained the upream Command and Conulhip. He Conquered Jugurtha in Affrick, and led him in Triumph: So great was the opinion of his Valour and Conduct, that when the Invaion of the Cimbrians and Teutons, had filled Italy with Terror and Confuion; Marius was the only Man that was thought fit to defend his Country, and on that occaion was five times ucceively choen Conul; and at lat in two Battles overcame the vat Armyes of the Cimbrians and Teutons, and Triumphed with a general Admiration and Applaue, as the Deliverer of his Country. The Poet puruing his Argument, hews his Long-Life was incommodious to him, for had he (ays the Poet) dyed the day of Triumph, no man had ever left behind him a more glorious Memory and Character: whereas, he after ullyed the Glory of his Reputation and Actions, and urvived his great Reputation, and for his Folly and Cruelty was corned and deteted of all, and o weariome to himelf, that he at lat dipatched his mierable Life. Page 45th.

(32) Great Pompey: Who having before the Civil Wars performed everal great Actions, fell ick at Capua of a Feavor; his death (the Poet ays) was then prevented by the publick Prayers that were made for his Recovery; but had he then dyed, his Head had happily ecaped an ignominious Death; Fortune eeming then to reerve it, to be cut off by the treachery of Achillas in Aegypt, and preented to his great Rival of the World, Julius Caear, who (Crocodile like) hed tears (no doubt of joy) over it. Page 46th.

(33) Cataline: The Poet oberves that Lentulus and Cethegus Traytors and Conpirators with Cataline, dyed a more decent death, than unfortunate Pompey, as not being beheaded or mangled, which was eteemed unfortunate and dihonoured: Cataline the Arch Traytor, dyed at the Head of his Army Gallantly fighting, and made a good Figure, covering the Spot where he ought. Page 47th.

(34) Lucretia: He paes now from Long-Life, & coniders the many diatrous fates have attended Innocent & Beautiful Perons; producing the Roman Lucrece for an Example, who being ravihed by Tarquinius Sextus, was the occaion of many troubles, and nobly ended her Life & Dihonor with a Ponyard. Page 48th.

(35) Virginia: With whoe rare Beauty, Appius Claudius the Decemvir fell deperately in Love, and having tryed all means to corrupt her Chatity without ucces, at lat uborns a Creature of his own, to wear before him as Judge, that Virginia was not the true Daughter of Lucius Virginius the Centurion her reputed Father, but a lave born, and conequently, ought not to be free, and was judged as a lave; by which judgment, he was abandoned (without her Fathers Protection) to the Lut of her Raviher; which Virginius perceiving, eeming atisfyed with the Sentence, deired to take leave off his uppoed Daughter, & approaching her, tabbed Her with his Dagger; whereby he prevented her Dihonor, & diapointed the Intent of the unjut Judge; it not being punihable in him to kill Her, being adjudged a lave, & taking the bleeding Body on his houlders, he returned with it to the Camp, where hewing the bloody Corps, and declaring his Injury, the Souldiers were tirred up to revenge his Wrong, which was punihed in the unjut Judge with Death, and occaioned the Extinguihing of the Government, in the Decem-viri. Page 48th.

(36) Mullet: The Poet oberves, that beautiful Sons are obnoxious to the Temptations of Great Men, and often Careed by wanton Wives and Ladies; though they mut expect ometimes to be taken, like their Predeceor Mars, who notwithtanding his Planet and his Sentinel the Cock was taken in Vulcans Net; where they mut expect all the Cruelty and Outrage, Injured and Revengful Men can commit: and mentions here the Roman Revenge, that ued to force a Mullet up the Fundament of the Offender, with the Head foremot, which having Britles on the Back, and Finns like a Pearch, was no way to be pulled out. Page 51t.

(37) Bellerephon: The Author hews that Beauty in young men, accompanied with a Reolution of rigied Vertue, turns very often to the diadvantage of the Poeor, which is made out by the Examples of Belerephon & Hippolito: with the Shape and Beauty of the firt of which Sthenobea the Wife of Praetus, the King of the Argives being Inamoured, ollicited him to unlawful Pleaures, which he refued; whereupon he accued him for attempting a Rape upon her; which occaioned many Hazards and Dangers, which his Vertue at lat overcame: Hippolito being a very Beautiful Youth, gave himelf up wholly to the Diverion of Hunting, regardles of the Charms and Converation of Women, with whom his Step-Mother P • aedra
• ell in love, and Courted him to her Bed, but was by him refued; he accues him to her Husband, for attempting a Rape upon her, Hiplito perceiving he had gained Belief of her eay Husband, and that his Life was in danger, Flies in his Chariot; but in the way his Hores being affrightened,
would not be governed, but running down a Precipice, dragged the unfortunate Youth in peices. Thee with the Story of Joeph may be a Caution to Cuckolds, not to be over Credulous. Page 53d.

(38) The Emperors Wife Mealina: She was married young, to Claudius the Old doating Emperor: Her alacious Appetite was not to be atisfied, though with many Incumbents: She played a tryal of skill for a prize, with one of the Ablet, and mot Famous Roman Courtezans, who hould endure the mot Aailants; in which Contet, the Empres bore away the Bell, and out-did the profet Harlot in her own Art: She ued in a diguie, to go to the Publick Stews by night, and there accoutred like a common Courtezan, he maintained her Pot againt all Commers, and in everal Incounters was found Invincible, taying till the Brothel Tap-too went about, as deirous to ee the lat Man born: At lat he grew o openly Extravagant, that being in love with Caius Silius a handome Youth, and of a mot Noble Family; made him put his Wife away and openly marry Her, though the Emperor her Husband was alive, and not twenty miles from Rome; for which Purpoe all Ceremonies were prepared for the Wedding, and the Portion ready down upon the nayle, the Wedding Bed prepared in a umptuous Pavilion in the Garden, of which the Emperour being advertied, forbid the Banes, and cauing both to be eied, they both were lain; the Unfortunate Silius, firt uffering before the eyes of the Lutful Emperes. Page 56th.

(39) Alcides: Hercules the Son of Jupiter and Al • mena; he was for his Jutice, Valour, and hardy Exploits, worthily tranlated among the Gods. The Poet propoes his Toyles and Labours, rather to be imitated and undergone, by a Brave and Virtuous Man, and preferrable to the Indulgence and Debauchery of a Sloathful and Voluptuous Peron. Page lt.

(40) Sardanapalus: The lat of the Ayrian Monarchs, and the 30th. from Ninus the Founder: He o degenerated into all the orts of Lut and Debauchery; that he was not ahamed to it and pin among a Multitude of Strumpets, And therefore was by the Ayrian Nobility worthily depied and depoed. Page lt.

div.head: Cato his Anwer to Labienus when he Requeted him to Conult the Oracle of Jupiter Ammon.
Being a Tranlation of Part of the 9th. Book of Lucan; Begining at—Quid quaeri Labiene Jubes, &c.
div.l: WHat hould I Ask my Friend, if best it be
To Live Enlav'd, or thus in Arms Dy free?
If it our Real Happines import,
Whither Life's foolih Scene be Long or Short?
If any Force true Honour can Abate,
Or Fortune's Threats make Vertue bow to Fate?
If when at Noble Ends we justly aim,
The Bare Attempt Entitles us to Fame?
If a Bad Caue that Jutice would oppres,
Can ever grow more Honet by Succes?
All this we know, wove in our Mind it ticks,
Which Ammon nor his Priets can deeper fix.
They need not Teach with Venale Cant and Pains
That God's Inevitable Will holds ours in Chains,
Who Act but only what he Praeordaines.
He needs no Voice to Thunder out his Law,
Or keep his Creatures Wild Deires in awe:
Both what we ought to do or what forbear,
He once for All did at our Births declare:
What for our Knowledge, needful was or fit
With Lating Characters in Humane Soul he Writ.
But never did he eek out Deert Lands
To Skulk, or Bury Truth in pathles Sands:
Or to a Corner of the World withdrew
Head of a Sect, and Partial to a few.
Natures Vat Fabrick he Controuls alone;
This Globe's his Foottool, and high Heaven his Throne;
In Earth, Sea, Air, and what e're ele Excels,
In Knowing Heads, and Honet Hearts he dwels.
Why vainly eek we then in Barren Sands
And narrow Shrines, in Temples Built with Hands,
HIM, whoe Dread Preence does all Places fill,
Or look, but in our Reaon, for his Will.
What e're we ee is GOD, in all we find
Apparent Prints of his Eternal Mind.
Let Floating Fools their Coure by Prophets Steer,
And live of future Chances till in Fear:
No Oracle or Dream the Crowd is told,
Shall make me more or les Reolv'd and Bold:
Death is my ure Retreat, which mut on All
As well on Cowards, as on the Gallant fall.
This aid, he turn'd him with Didain about,
And left corn'd Ammon to amue the Rout.
